{{short description|Auto race run in Texas in 1979}} {{NASCAR race season infobox | Type = CUST | Description = Race 14 of 31 in the [[1979 NASCAR Winston Cup Series]] season | country = United States | Race Name = Texas 400 | Details ref = {{cite web | url = http://www.almanac.com/weather/history/TX/College%20Station/1979-06-09| title = 1979 Texas 400 weather information | publisher = The Old Farmers' Almanac | accessdate = 2012-09-10|}} | Fulldate = {{Start date|1979|June|9}} | Year = 1979 | Race_No = 14 | Season_No = 31 | Image = Texas World Speedway-Superspeedway.svg | Caption = Layout of Texas World Speedway | Official name = Texas 400 | Location = [[Texas World Speedway]], [[College Station, Texas]] | Course_mi = 2.000 | Course_km = 3.218 | Distance_laps = 200 | Distance_mi = 400 | Distance_km = 643.738 | Weather = Hot with temperatures approaching {{convert|90|F|C}}; wind speeds up to {{convert|11.8|mph|km/h}} | Avg = {{convert|156.216|mi/h}} | Attendance = 11,500{{cite web | url = http://racing-reference.info/race/1979_Texas_400/W| title = 1979 Texas 400 racing results | publisher = Racing Reference | accessdate = 2011-11-14 |}} | Pole_Driver = [[Buddy Baker]] | Pole_Team = [[Ranier Racing]] | Pole_Time = | Most_Driver = [[Darrell Waltrip]] | Most_Team = [[DiGard Motorsports]] | Most_laps = 155 | Car = 88 | First_Driver = Darrell Waltrip | First_Team = DiGard Motorsports | Network = untelevised | Announcers = none }} The '''1979 Texas 400''' was a [[NASCAR]] [[Monster Energy NASCAR Cup Series|Winston Cup Series]] (now Monster Energy NASCAR Cup Series) race that took place on June 3, 1979, at [[Texas World Speedway]] in [[College Station, Texas]]. By [[1980 NASCAR Winston Cup Series|the following season]], NASCAR had completely stopped tracking the year model of all the vehicles and most teams did not take stock cars to the track under their own power anymore. Only manual transmission vehicles were allowed to participate in this race; a policy that NASCAR has retained to the present day. ==Summary== Two hundred laps took place on an [[Oval track racing|oval track]] spanning {{convert|2.0|mi|km}}. [[Darrell Waltrip]] won the race; beating [[Bobby Allison]] by 60 seconds. Eleven thousand and five hundred fans would attend this live race with lasted more than two hours and thirty-three minutes; making it the least attended race in NASCAR's modern era even when comparing races from after the [[2008 NASCAR Sprint Cup Series]] season. Waltrip's overall speed for the race was {{convert|156.216|mi/h|km/h}} while [[Buddy Baker]] achieved the pole position for the race with a speed of {{convert|167.903|mi/h|km/h}}. Total winnings for this race were $161,250 (${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|161250|1979|r=2}}}} when considering inflation); Darrell would receive $21,750 of the total purse (${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|21750|1979|r=2}}}} when considering inflation). Dale Earnhardt was Waltrip's top challenger before he crashed late in the race. Waltrip had a lap lead but Allison, Baker, and Yarborough had a one-lap dash for second. Allison got second by about two feet over Baker, who was about four feet back. Some of the more notable names to make an appearance here were: [[Dale Earnhardt]], [[Richard Childress]], [[Cale Yarborough]], [[Terry Labonte]], [[Richard Petty]], and [[J. D. McDuffie]]. Notable crew chiefs in attendance for this race were [[Buddy Parrott]], [[Joey Arrington]], [[Kirk Shelmerdine]], [[Darrell Bryant]], [[Dale Inman]], [[Bud Moore (NASCAR owner)|Bud Moore]], [[Tim Brewer]], and [[Jake Elder]].{{cite web | url = https://www.racing-reference.info/entrylist/1979-14/W/C| title = 1979 Texas 400 crew chiefs information | publisher = Racing Reference | accessdate = 2018-08-23|}} While [[Jim Hurlbert]] and [[John Rezek]] would make their NASCAR Cup Series debut, [[Billy Hagan (racing driver)|Billy Hagan]] would make his grand exit after this race along with three other drivers. [[Bill Meazel]] would make his only NASCAR appearance during this event.{{cite web | url = http://www.race-database.com/results/results.php?year=1979&race=14&series_id=2| title = Notable events at the ''1979 Texas 400'' | publisher = Race Database | accessdate = 2014-05-08|}} ===Qualifying=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! [[File:aicmctx-06champs.jpg|thumb|CMC and AI cars racing in Texas.]] '''American Iron''' is a group of North American [[road racing]] classes sanctioned by the [[National Auto Sport Association]] (NASA).
'''American Iron''' racing features domestic muscle or [[pony cars]] such as [[Ford Mustang]], [[Chevrolet Camaro]], and [[Pontiac Firebird]] in four classes, '''Camaro Mustang Challenge (CMC & CMC-II),''' '''American Iron (AI),''' and '''American Iron Extreme (AIX)'''. It has large, closely contested fields of V8 powered cars.
The different classes reflect various levels of permitted modifications, from the near showroom stock entry level Camaro Mustang Challenge (CMC) class, through to the "almost anything goes" American Iron Extreme (AIX) class at the opposite end of the scale. CMC, CMC-II, and AI classes have a power to weight limitation, while AIX is unrestricted.
The minimum weight for an American Iron race car is 2,700 pounds with driver included. The AI class has a maximum power to weight ratio of 9.5:1 (9.5 lbs of vehicle weight per horsepower) and a maximum torque to weight ratio of 9:1 (9 pounds of vehicle weight per each foot-pound). Both are measured at the rear wheels. These formulas are designed to allow differences in vehicle handling and power while equalizing the competition and keeping race team budgets low by penalizing excessive power.
'''American Iron''' races are run at all [http://www.nasaproracing.com/aboutnasa/regions.html NASA regional] events, as well as the annual National Championships currently held each year in September at [[Miller Motorsports Park]] in Tooele, Utah. Previously, the championships were held at [[Mid-Ohio Sports Car Course]].
==External links== *[http://americanironracing.com/ American Iron Official Site] *[http://www.camaromustangchallenge.com/ Camaro Mustang Challenge Official Site] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061116191249/http://www.nasaproracing.com/rules/American-Iron-Rules.pdf American Iron rules (PDF)] *[http://www.nasaproracing.com/rules/Camaro-Mustang-Challenge.pdf Camaro Mustang Challenge rules (PDF)] *[http://www.aicmctexas.com/ AI/CMC Texas Region Site] *[http://www.trackvids.com/how-to-build-a-mustang-race-car-for-american-iron-and-super-touring.php How to Build a Mustang Race Car for American Iron]

'''Autoclasica''' is an elegance competition for [[classic car|classic]] and [[vintage cars]]. It has taken place every year since 1998 during the first weekend of October in [[San Isidro, Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]]. The event is the largest in South America, with more than 600 vehicles on display.
The show takes place the first week of October at the [[Hipódromo de San Isidro]] gardens, organized by the Club de Automoviles Clasicos (CAC), of Argentina.

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} {{Use British English|date=November 2013}} {{for|the film ''Barnet Horse Fair''|Barnet Horse Fair (film)}} [[File:Barnet Fair c. 1849.jpg|thumbnail|Cattle at Barnet Fair c. 1849]] [[File:Horse Fair Barnet.jpg|thumbnail|Barnet horse fair]] [[File:Barnet fair view.jpg|thumbnail|The funfair]] '''Barnet Fair''' is an annual horse and pleasure fair held near Mays Lane, [[Chipping Barnet|Barnet]], [[England]], on the first Monday in September.<ref name="BarnetOnline">{{cite web|title=Barnet Market and Fair |url=http://www.barnet.gov.uk/index/leisure-culture/libraries/archives/archives-histories/archives-barnethistories/archives-barnet-barnetmarket.htm |work=Barnet Online |accessdate=13 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607174613/http://www.barnet.gov.uk/index/leisure-culture/libraries/archives/archives-histories/archives-barnethistories/archives-barnet-barnetmarket.htm |archivedate=7 June 2011 }}</ref>
The Fair takes place over three days starting on 4 September. It still operates under its royal Charter which is issued by Barnet council. The focus in the present-day Fair is no longer on horses and other livestock; but it is rather a pleasure fair instead.
==History== The fair began in 1588 when [[Queen Elizabeth I]] granted a charter to the Lord of the Manor of Barnet to hold a fair twice yearly, in addition to the weekly [[Barnet Market]].<ref name="Barnet4U">{{cite web|title=Barnet Fair |url=http://barnet4u.co.uk/Barnet%20History/barnetfair.html |work=Barnet 4U |accessdate=13 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101208035059/http://www.barnet4u.co.uk/Barnet%20History/barnetfair.html |archivedate=8 December 2010 |df=dmy }}</ref> Originally held in June and October, Lord John Tomlinson changed the dates to April and September in 1758 for the reason of improving business.<ref name="Barnet4U"/> From 1881, the April fair ceased.<ref name="Barnet4U"/>
The focus of the fair was its livestock, with animals being brought from across the [[United Kingdom]].<ref name="BarnetOnline"/><ref name="Barnet4U"/> In 1834, ''[[The Times]]'' reported that Barnet Fair was England's largest cattle market, with up to 40,000 animals on display.<ref name="Barnet4U"/>
From the eighteenth century, the festivities also used to include horse racing, although these ceased in 1870 when the railway station was built on the ground in which they had been held.<ref name="BarnetOnline"/><ref name="Barnet4U"/>
==Popular culture== In 1896, a film was made about Barnet Fair, entitled ''[[Barnet Horse Fair (film)|Barnet Horse Fair]]''.
The term 'Barnet Fair', normally shortened to 'Barnet', has become [[rhyming slang]] for 'hair'.<ref>Julian Franklyn, ''A Dictionary of Rhyming Slang'' ([[Routledge]], 1960).</ref>
"Barnet Fair" is the name of a song by [[Steeleye Span]].

[[Warren Anderson (American businessman)|Warren Anderson]] | mute = | setting = [[Bhopal]], [[India]] | premiere = 2001 | place = | orig_lang = English with some French and Hindi | series = | subject = [[Bhopal disaster]] | genre = | web = }} {{unreferenced|date=July 2010}} '''''Bhopal''''' is a play by Canadian playwright Rahul Varma about the [[Bhopal disaster]]. ==Production history== It premiered in 2001 produced by [[Teesri Duniya]] and directed by [[Jack Langedijk]]. It used a non-realistic, live music, minimalist set and a chorus. It was translated into [[Hindi]] as Zahreeli Hawa in 2003 by translator/director [[Habib Tanvir]]. It was produced by Cahoots Theatre Projects in 2003 at the Theatre Centre in Toronto, directed by Guillermo Verdecchia. The set consisted of a wall of dirty rags and sand on the floor. It was translated into French in 2005 by translator Paul Lefebvre and performed at Theatre Periscope in Quebec City and in Montreal at the Espace Libre. Directed by Philippe Soldevilla. Eight actors performed all the rolls with [[wikt:doubling|doubling]] and with added dance. The set was made up of wooden blocks moved into different configurations. ''Bhopal'' was published in 2004 by [[Playwrights Canada Press]]. ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101109104403/http://www.playwrightscanada.com/plays/bhopal.html Playwrights Canada Press] {{DEFAULTSORT:Bhopal (Play)}} [[Category:Canadian plays]] [[Category:Bhopal disaster]] [[Category:2001 plays]] [[Category:Plays based on actual events]] [[Category:Plays set in India]] {{2000s-play-stub}}

{{distinguish|bushfood}} [[File:Varanus bitatawa stew being prepared by Agta tribesmen - ZooKeys-266-001-g071.jpg|thumb|The lizard ''[[Varanus bitatawa]]'' is a common food for indigenous people in parts of the Philippines.]]
'''Bushmeat''', '''wildmeat''', or '''game meat''' is [[meat]] from non-domesticated [[mammal]]s, [[reptiles]], [[amphibians]] and [[birds]] hunted for food in [[tropical forest]]s.<ref name=scbd2008>{{cite book | last1 = Nasi | first1 = R. | last2 = Brown | first2 = D. | last3 = Wilkie | first3 = D. | last4 = Bennett | first4 = E. | last5 = Tutin | first5 = C. | last6 = Van Tol | first6 = G. | last7 = Christophersen | first7 = T. | year = 2008 | title = Conservation and use of wildlife-based resources: the bushmeat crisis | publisher = Secretariat of the Convention on Biological Diversity and Center for International Forestry Research (CIFOR) | series = CBD Technical Series no. 33 | pages = 1–50 | url = http://re.indiaenvironmentportal.org.in/files/Conservation%20and%20use%20of%20wildlife-based%20resources.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = October 22, 2014}}</ref> Commercial harvesting and the trade of [[wildlife]] is considered a threat to [[biodiversity]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Cowlishaw | first1 = G. | last2 = Mendelson | first2 = S. | last3 = Rowcliffe | first3 = J. | title = Evidence for post‐depletion sustainability in a mature bushmeat market | year = 2005 | journal = Journal of Applied Ecology | volume = 42 | issue = 3 | pages = 460–468 | doi = 10.1111/j.1365-2664.2005.01046.x}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2016/10/people-are-hunting-primates-bats-and-other-mammals-extinction|title=People are hunting primates, bats, and other mammals to extinction|first= Elizabeth|last=Pennisi|date=October 18, 2016|work=[[Science (magazine)|Science]]|accessdate=May 26, 2017}}</ref>
Bushmeat also provides a route for a number of serious [[tropical disease]]s to spread to humans from their animal hosts. These include [[Ebola]].<ref>{{Cite journal |pmid=19787649 |year=2009 |author1=Karesh |first1=W. B. |title=The bushmeat trade: Increased opportunities for transmission of zoonotic disease |journal=Mount Sinai Journal of Medicine: A Journal of Translational and Personalized Medicine |volume=76 |issue=5 |pages=429–444 |last2=Noble |first2=E. |doi=10.1002/msj.20139}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |pmid=23408099 |year=2012 |author1=Subramanian |first1=M. |title=Zoonotic disease risk and the bushmeat trade: Assessing awareness among hunters and traders in Sierra Leone |journal=EcoHealth |volume=9 |issue=4 |pages=471–482 |doi=10.1007/s10393-012-0807-1}}</ref> Bushmeat is used for sustenance in remote areas, while in major towns and cities in bushmeat eating societies it is treated as a delicacy.<ref name="BBC_18Oct2014"/>
== Nomenclature == Today the term ''bushmeat'' is commonly used for meat of [[terrestrial animal|terrestrial]] wild or feral mammals, killed for sustenance or commercial purposes throughout the humid [[tropics]] of the Americas, Asia, and Africa. In West Africa (primarily [[Ghana]], [[Ivory Coast]], and [[Nigeria]]), ''[[Achatina achatina]]'', a giant African snail, is also gathered, sold, eaten, and monitored as part of the bushmeat trade.<ref name=FAO>{{cite web|author=Forestry Department|title=Wildlife utilization and food security in Africa|url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/w7540e/w7540e0i.htm|website=www.fao.org|publisher=FAO|accessdate=14 February 2015}}</ref><ref name=BCTF>{{cite web|title=Document on the breeding of the giant African snail (Achatina achatina)|url=http://www.bushmeat.org/node/623|publisher=Bushmeat Crisis Task Force|accessdate=14 February 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150214115207/http://www.bushmeat.org/node/623#|archive-date=2015-02-14|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Ebola scares West Africans away from bush meat|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/ebola-virus-scares-west-africans-away-from-bush-meat/|accessdate=14 February 2015|agency=AP|publisher=CBS News|date=October 29, 2014}}</ref> To reflect the global nature of [[hunting]] of wild animals, Resolution 2.64 of the [[IUCN]] General Assembly in [[Amman]] in October 2000 referred to ''wild meat'' rather than ''bushmeat''. A more worldwide term for terrestrial wild animals is [[game (food)|game]]. The term ''bushmeat crisis'' is sometimes used to describe unsustainable hunting of often [[Endangered species|endangered]] wild mammals in West and Central Africa and the humid tropics, depending on interpretation. African hunting predates recorded history; by the 21st century, it had become an international issue.<ref name="Ecosystems">{{cite book |title=Ecosystems and Human Well-Being: Current State and Trends. Findings of the Condition and Trends Working Group |editor=Hassan, R. M. |editor2=Scholes, R. |editor3=Ash, N. |publisher=Island Press |pages=407 |year=2005 |isbn=1-55963-228-3 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UFVmiSAr-okC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
== Extent == The volume of the bushmeat trade in [[West Africa|West]] and [[Central Africa]] was estimated at 1-5 million tonnes per year at the turn of the century.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Davies | first1 = G. | title = Bushmeat and international development | journal = Conservation Biology | volume = 16 | issue = 3 | year = 2002 | pages = 587–589 | doi = 10.1046/j.1523-1739.2002.01636.x}}</ref> According to the [[Center for International Forestry Research]] (CIFOR) in 2014, approximately 5 million tonnes were still being consumed per year in the [[Congo Basin]].<ref name="BBC_18Oct2014"/>
For the people of this region, bushmeat represents a primary source of animal [[protein]] in the diet, making it a significant commercial industry. According to a 1994 study in [[Gabon]], annual sales were estimated at US$50 million. The study found that bushmeat accounted for more than half of meat sold in local markets, with [[primates]] representing 20% of the total bushmeat.<ref name="PanAfricaNews1996"/>
== Dynamics == [[File:Hunted Silky Sifakas.jpg|thumb|250px|alt=Two Malagasy hunters stand near a stream, one holding a gun, the other holding a lemur with a white head.|Endangered species, including [[lemur]]s from [[Madagascar]] and great apes are killed for bushmeat despite this being illegal. Pictured: Two men with weapons and their prey arranged on display.]] [[File:Bushmeat - Buschfleisch Ghana.JPG|thumb|Bushmeat is often smoked prior to consumption.]]
=== Logging penetration of forests === [[Logging]] concessions operated by companies in African forests have been closely linked to the bushmeat trade. Because they provide roads, trucks and other access to remote forests, they are the primary means for the transportation of hunters and meat between forests and urban centres. Some, including the Congolaise Industrielle du Bois (CIB) in the [[Republic of Congo]], have partnered with governments and international conservation organizations to regulate the bushmeat trade within the concessions where they operate. Numerous solutions are needed; because each country has different circumstances, traditions and laws, no one solution will work in every location.<ref>Poulsen, J. R., Clark, C. J., Mavah, G., & Elkan, P. W. (2009). [https://www.researchgate.net/publication/24444051_Bushmeat_supply_and_consumption_in_a_tropical_logging_concession_in_northern_Congo/file/9c96051f8644074d87.pdf Bushmeat supply and consumption in a tropical logging concession in northern Congo.] Conservation Biology 23(6): 1597–1608.</ref>
=== Overfishing === In the case of [[Ghana]], international over-exploitation of African [[Fisheries|fishing grounds]] has increased demand for bushmeat. Both [[European Union|EU]]-subsidized fleets and local commercial fleets have depleted fish stocks, leaving local people to supplement their diets with animals hunted from nature reserves. Over 30 years of data link sharp declines in both mammal populations and the biomass of 41 wildlife species with a decreased supply of fish.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Brashares | first1 = J. S. | last2 = Arcese | first2 = P. | last3 = Sam | first3 = M. K. | last4 = Coppolillo | first4 = P. B. | last5 = Sinclair | first5 = A. R. E. | last6 = Balmford | first6 = A. | title = Bushmeat hunting, wildlife declines, and fish supply in West Africa | journal = Science | year = 2004 | volume = 306 | issue = 5699 | pages = 1180–1183 | doi = 10.1126/science.1102425 | url = http://www.zoology.ubc.ca/courses/bio416/Brashares_etal_Science04.pdf | format = PDF | pmid=15539602}}</ref>
=== Public preference === In the case of [[Liberia]] in West Africa, bushmeat is eaten widely and is considered a delicacy.<ref name="Wynfred Russell"/> A 2004 public opinion survey found that bushmeat ranked second behind fish among residents of the capital [[Monrovia]] as a preferred source of protein.<ref name="Wynfred Russell"/> Of households where bushmeat was served, 80% of residents said they cooked it "once in a while", while 13% cooked it once a week and 7% cooked bushmeat daily.<ref name="Wynfred Russell"/> The survey was conducted during the last civil war, and bushmeat consumption is now believed to be far higher.<ref name="Wynfred Russell">{{Cite web |url=http://www.frontpageafricaonline.com/index.php/op-ed/commentaries-features/380-extinction-is-forever-a-crisis-that-is-liberia-s-endangered-wildlife# |title="Extinction is forever: A crisis that is Liberia's endangered wildlife", Wynfred Russell |publisher=[[FrontPage Africa]] |access-date=2014-10-31 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303191753/http://www.frontpageafricaonline.com/index.php/op-ed/commentaries-features/380-extinction-is-forever-a-crisis-that-is-liberia-s-endangered-wildlife# |archive-date=2016-03-03 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
== Role in spread of diseases == The transmission of highly variable [[retrovirus]] chains causes [[zoonotic disease]]s. Outbreaks of the [[Ebola virus]] in the [[Congo Basin]] and in [[Gabon]] in the 1990s have been associated with the butchering of [[Pan (genus)|apes]] and consumption of their meat.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Georges-Courbot, M. C. | author2 = Sanchez, A. | author3 = Lu, C. Y. | author4 = Baize, S. | author5 = Leroy, E. | author6 = Lansout-Soukate, J. | author7 = Tévi-Bénissan, C. | author8 = Georges, A. J. | author9 = Trappier, S. G. | author10 = Zaki, S. R. | author11 = Swanepoel, R. | author12 = Leman, P. A. | author13 = Rollin, P. E. | author14 = Peters, C. J. | author15 = Nichol, S. T. | author16 = T. G. Ksiazek | last-author-amp = yes | year = 1997 | title = Isolation and phylogenetic characterization of Ebola viruses causing different outbreaks in Gabon | journal = Emerging Infectious Diseases | volume = 3 | issue = 1 | pages = 59–62 | doi = 10.3201/eid0301.970107 | url = https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2627600/pdf/9126445.pdf | format = PDF | pmid=9126445 | pmc=2627600}}</ref> Bushmeat hunters in [[Central Africa]] infected with the [[human T-lymphotropic virus]] were closely exposed to wild [[primate]]s.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Wolfe, N. D. | author2 = Heneine, W. | author3 = Carr, J. K. | author4 = Garcia, A. D. | author5 = Shanmugam, V. | author6 = Tamoufe, U. | author7 = Torimiro, J. N. | author8 = Prosser, A. T. | author9 = Lebreton, M. | author10 = Mpoudi-Ngole, E. | author11 = McCutchan, F. E. | author12 = Birx, D. L. | author13 = Folks, T. M. | author14 = Burke, D. S. | author15 = Switzer, W. M. | year = 2005 | title = Emergence of unique primate T-lymphotropic viruses among central African bushmeat hunters | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | volume = 102 | issue = 22 | pages = 7994–7999 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0501734102 | pmid=15911757 | pmc=1142377}}</ref>
=== HIV === Results of research on wild [[Pan troglodytes troglodytes|chimpanzees]] in [[Cameroon]] indicate that they are naturally infected with the [[simian foamy virus]] and constitute a reservoir of [[HIV-1]], a precursor of the [[acquired immunodeficiency syndrome]] (AIDS) in [[human]]s.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Keele | first1 = B. F. | last2 = Van Heuverswyn | first2 = F. | last3 = Li | first3 = Y. | last4 = Bailes | first4 = E. | last5 = Takehisa | first5 = J. | last6 = Santiago | first6 = M. L. | last7 = Bibollet-Ruche | first7 = F. | last8 = Chen | first8 = Y. | last9 = Wain | first9 = L. V. | last10 = Liegeois | first10 = F. | last11 = Loul | first11 = S. | last12 = Ngole | first12 = E. M. | last13 = Bienvenue | first13 = Y. | last14 = Delaporte | first14 = E. | last15 = Brookfield | first15 = J. F. | last16 = Sharp | first16 = P. M. | last17 = Shaw | first17 = G. M. | last18 = Peeters | first18 = M. | last19 = Hahn | first19 = B. H. | year = 2006 | title = Chimpanzee reservoirs of pandemic and nonpandemic HIV-1 | url = | journal = Science | volume = 313 | issue = 5786| pages = 523–526 | doi=10.1126/science.1126531 | pmid=16728595 | pmc=2442710}}</ref> There are several distinct strains of HIV, indicating that this cross-species transfer has occurred several times.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Sharp |first1= P. M. | last2 = Hahn |first2 = B. H. | year = 2011 | title = Origins of HIV and the AIDS Pandemic | journal = Cold Spring Harbor Perspectives in Medicine | volume = 1 | issue = 1 | pages = a006841–a006835 | doi = 10.1101/cshperspect.a006841 | url = http://perspectivesinmedicine.org/content/1/1/a006841.full.pdf+html | pmid=22229120 | pmc=3234451}} </ref> Researchers have shown that HIV originated from a similar virus in primates called [[simian immunodeficiency virus]] (SIV); it is likely that HIV was initially transferred to humans after having come into contact with infected bushmeat.<ref>{{cite news | title = Scientists find new strain of HIV | publisher = BBC News | date = 2 August 2009 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/8175379.stm}}</ref>{{mcn|date=November 2017}}
=== Ebola === The Ebola virus, for which the primary host is suspected to be [[Megabat|fruit bats]], has been linked to bushmeat. Between the first recorded outbreak in 1976 and the largest in 2014, the virus has [[Spillover infection|transferred from animals to humans]] only 30 times, despite large numbers of bats being killed and sold each year.<ref name="BBC_18Oct2014"/> Bats drop partially eaten fruits and pulp, then land mammals such as gorillas and [[duiker]]s feed on these fallen fruits. This chain of events forms a possible indirect means of transmission from the natural host to animal populations.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Gonzalez JP, Pourrut X, Leroy E |title=Ebolavirus and other filoviruses |journal=Current Topics in Microbiology and Immunology |volume=315 |pages=363–387 |year=2007 |pmid=17848072 |doi=10.1007/978-3-540-70962-6_15 |isbn=978-3-540-70961-9 |series=Current Topics in Microbiology and Immunology }}</ref>
Although primates and other species may be intermediates, evidence suggests people primarily contract the virus from bats. Since most people buy smoked bushmeat, hunters and people preparing the food have the highest risk of infection. Hunters usually shoot, net, scavenge or catapult their prey, and butcher the bats without gloves, getting bites or scratches and coming in contact with their blood.<ref name="BBC_18Oct2014">{{cite web | last1 = Hogenboom | first1 = Melissa | url = https://www.bbc.com/news/health-29604204 | publisher = BBC News | title = Ebola: Is bushmeat behind the outbreak? | date = October 18, 2014 | accessdate = October 21, 2014}}</ref><ref name=camghana>{{cite web|url=http://www.cam.ac.uk/research/news/understanding-the-bushmeat-market-why-do-people-risk-infection-from-bat-meat|title=Understanding the bushmeat market: why do people risk infection from bat meat?|work=Research News|publisher=University of Cambridge}}</ref>
In 2014, the suspected [[index case]] for the [[Ebola virus epidemic in West Africa|Ebola outbreak in West Africa]] is a two-year-old child in [[Guéckédou Prefecture|Guéckédou]] in south-eastern Guinea, who was the child of a family that hunted two species of fruit bat,<ref name="BBC_18Oct2014"/> ''[[Hammer-headed bat|Hypsignathus monstrosus]]'' and ''[[Franquet's epauletted fruit bat|Epomops franqueti]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/news-stories/voice-field/struggling-contain-ebola-epidemic-west-africa | publisher = MSF USA | title = Struggling to Contain the Ebola Epidemic in West Africa | date = July 8, 2014 | accessdate = October 21, 2014}}</ref> Some researchers suggested the case was caused by [[Zoonosis|zoonotic transmission]] through the child playing with an [[Microbat|insectivorous bat]] from a colony of [[Angolan free-tailed bat]]s near the village.<ref name=EMBOMM123014>{{cite journal|author=Almudena Marí Saéz|author2=Sabrina Weiss|author3=Kathrin Nowak|author4=Vincent Lapeyre|author5=Fee Zimmermann|author6=Ariane Düx|author7=Hjalmar S Kühl|author8=Moussa Kaba|author9=Sebastien Regnaut|author10=Kevin Merkel|author11=Andreas Sachse|author12=Ulla Thiesen|author13=Lili Villányi|author14=Christophe Boesch|author15=Piotr W Dabrowski|author16=Aleksandar Radonić|author17=Andreas Nitsche|author18=Siv Aina J Leendertz|author19=Stefan Petterson|author20=Stephan Becker|author21=Verena Krähling|author22=Emmanuel Couacy‐Hymann|author23=Chantal Akoua‐Koffi|author24=Natalie Weber|author25=Lars Schaade|author26=Jakob Fahr|author27=Matthias Borchert|author28=Jan F Gogarten|author29=Sébastien Calvignac‐Spencer|author30=Fabian H Leendertz|title=Investigating the zoonotic origin of the West African Ebola epidemic|journal=EMBO Molecular Medicine|date=December 30, 2014|issue=Published online|doi=10.15252/emmm.201404792|url=http://embomolmed.embopress.org/content/early/2014/12/29/emmm.201404792|accessdate=December 31, 2014|publisher=EMBO Press|format=online|quote=The severe Ebola virus disease epidemic occurring in West Africa likely stems from a single zoonotic transmission event involving a 2 year old boy in Meliandou, Guinea, who might have been infected by hunting or playing with insectivorous free‐tailed bats living in a nearby hollow tree|volume=7|pages=17–23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/csr/disease/ebola/ebola-6-months/guinea/en/|title=Ground zero in Guinea: the outbreak smoulders – undetected – for more than 3 months|work=World Health Organization}}</ref>
Despite health organisations warning about risks of bushmeat, surveys pre-dating the 2014 outbreak indicate that people who eat bushmeat are usually unaware of the risks and view it as healthy food. Because of bushmeat's role as a protein source in Western Africa, it is traditionally associated with good nutrition, and efforts to outlaw the sale and consumption of bushmeat have been impossible to enforce and have met with suspicion from rural communities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fao.org/news/story/en/item/239123/icode/|title=FAO warns of fruit bat risk in West African Ebola epidemic|work=FAO|date=21 July 2014}}</ref> In one study in Ghana, none of the bushmeat hunters knew about Ghana's hunting laws, suggesting that bans may not be enforceable.<ref name=camghana/> The UN Food and Agriculture Organization estimates that between 30 and 80 percent of protein intake in rural households in Central Africa comes from wild meat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/programmes/en/empres/news_151010.html|title=Bushmeat consumption, wildlife trade and global public health risks|work=FAO|date=15 Oct 2010}}</ref> However, as [[Overpopulation|human populations grow]], the interactions between humans and wildlife will increase, making possible [[Zoonosis|zoonotic transmission]] of diseases from animal hosts more likely.<ref name="BBC_18Oct2014"/>
One major Nigerian newspaper published a report about the widespread view that eating [[dog meat]] was a healthy alternative to bush meat.<ref>Shobayo, I. (2014). [http://www.tribune.com.ng/arewa/item/13955-ebola-jos-residents-shun-bush-meat-stick-to-dog-meat/13955-ebola-jos-residents-shun-bush-meat-stick-to-dog-meat Jos residents shun bushmeat stick to dog meat.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141222003501/http://www.tribune.com.ng/arewa/item/13955-ebola-jos-residents-shun-bush-meat-stick-to-dog-meat/13955-ebola-jos-residents-shun-bush-meat-stick-to-dog-meat |date=2014-12-22 }} Nigerian Tribune, August 2014.</ref> Dog meat was implicated in a June 2015 Liberian outbreak of Ebola, where three villagers who had tested positive for the disease had shared a meal of dog meat.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/07/02/us-health-ebola-liberia-idUSKCN0PC0WJ20150702|title=Liberia investigating animal link after Ebola re-emerges|work=Reuters|date=2 Jul 2015}}</ref>
One study conducted in Liberia during the recent Ebola crisis showed that socio-economic conditions impacted bushmeat consumption. During the crisis, there was a decrease in bushmeat consumption and daily meal frequency. In addition, preferences for bushmeat species stayed the same.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ordaz-Németh|first=Isabel|last2=Arandjelovic|first2=Mimi|last3=Boesch|first3=Lukas|last4=Gatiso|first4=Tsegaye|last5=Grimes|first5=Trokon|last6=Kuehl|first6=Hjalmar S.|last7=Lormie|first7=Menladi|last8=Stephens|first8=Colleen|last9=Tweh|first9=Clement|date=2017-03-10|title=The socio-economic drivers of bushmeat consumption during the West African Ebola crisis|url=http://journals.plos.org/plosntds/article?id=10.1371/journal.pntd.0005450|journal=PLOS Neglected Tropical Diseases|language=en|volume=11|issue=3|pages=e0005450|doi=10.1371/journal.pntd.0005450|issn=1935-2735}}</ref>
===Other diseases=== Animals used as bushmeat may also carry other diseases such as [[smallpox]], [[chicken pox]], [[tuberculosis]], [[measles]], [[rubella]], [[rabies]], [[yellow fever]] and [[yaws]].<ref>McMichael, A. J. (2002). [http://www.hawaii.edu/hivandaids/Population,%20Environment,%20Disease,%20and%20Survival%20%20Past%20Patterns,%20Uncertain%20Futures.pdf Population, environment, disease, and survival: past patterns, uncertain futures.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060917091710/http://www.hawaii.edu/hivandaids/Population%2C%20Environment%2C%20Disease%2C%20and%20Survival%20%20Past%20Patterns%2C%20Uncertain%20Futures.pdf |date=September 17, 2006 }} The Lancet 359 (9312): 1145–1148.</ref> African squirrels (''[[Heliosciurus]]'', ''[[Funisciurus]]'') have been implicated as reservoirs of the [[monkeypox]] virus in the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Khodakevich | first1 = L. | last2 = Szczeniowski | first2 = M. | last3 = Jezek | first3 = Z. | last4 = Marennikova | first4 = S. | last5 = Nakano | first5 = J. | last6 = Messinger | first6 = D. | year = 1987 | title = The role of squirrels in sustaining monkeypox virus transmission | url = | journal = Tropical and geographical medicine | volume = 39 | issue = 2| pages = 115–122 }}</ref> The [[bubonic plague]] bacteria can transfer to humans when handling or eating North American [[prairie dog]]s.<ref>Walsh, P. (2005). [http://www.columbia.edu/itc/cerc/danoff-burg/invasion_bio/inv_spp_summ/Yersinia_pestis.htm Yersinua pestis: Bubonic plague.] University of Columbia</ref>
In many instances, contracting the diseases mentioned above often occurs due to the cutting of the meat, when animal blood and other fluids may touch the people cutting it, thereby infecting them. Another path of infection is that some of the meat may not be completely cooked. This often occurs due to the type of cooking method: hanging the meat over an open fire.<ref>Williams, E. (2012). Unreported World: The Monkey Business documentary. Channel 4, London.</ref> Improper preparation of any infected animal may be fatal.<ref>{{cite web |year=2012 | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/health-news/african-monkey-meat-that-could-be-behind-the-next-hiv-7786152.html | title = African monkey meat that could be behind the next HIV | publisher = The Independent | work = Health News - Health & Families | author = Williams, E. | quote = 25 people in Bakaklion, Cameroon killed due to eating of ape}}</ref>
== Impact upon animal species == {{See also|Elephant meat}} [[File:Choeropsis.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Pygmy hippo]]s are among the species [[Environmental issues in Liberia|illegally hunted for food in Liberia]].<ref name="Anne Look"/> The [[World Conservation Union]] estimates that there are fewer than 3,000 pygmy hippos remaining in the wild.<ref name="Redlist">{{IUCN |assessor=Ransom, C.|assessor2=Robinson, P.T. |assessor3=Collen, B. |last-assessor-amp=yes|year=2015 |id=10032|title=Choeropsis liberiensis |version=2016.2}}</ref>]]
The consumption of bushmeat threatens a wide range of species, including species that are endangered and threatened with extinction. For example, a range of endangered species are hunted for bushmeat in Liberia.<ref name="Anne Look"/>
Species hunted for food in Liberia include [[elephants]], [[pygmy hippopotamus]], [[chimpanzees]], [[duikers]], and other monkeys.<ref name="Anne Look">[http://www.voanews.com/content/article/370590.html "Poaching in Liberia's Forests Threatens Rare Animals", Anne Look, [[Voice of America]] News, May 08, 2012.]</ref> Forest rangers in Liberia say that bushmeat poachers will kill any forest animal they encounter.<ref name="Anne Look"/>
=== Effect on great apes === [[File:Gorilla gorilla09.jpg|thumb|250px|A gorilla in the [[DR Congo]], 2008. The use of [[Shotgun shell#Buckshot|buckshot]] has helped bushmeat hunters target gorillas by allowing them to more easily kill the dominant male [[silverback]].]]
The great apes of Central and West Africa—gorillas and chimpanzees—are nearly ubiquitously sold as bushmeat throughout the region, and a study from 1995 suggests that the off-take is unsustainable.<ref name="PanAfricaNews1996">{{cite journal | last1 = Rose | first1 = A. L. | title = The African great ape bushmeat crisis | year = 1996 | publisher = Mahale Wildlife Conservation Society | journal = Pan Africa News | volume = 3 | issue = 2 | pages = 1–6 | url = http://repository.kulib.kyoto-u.ac.jp/dspace/bitstream/2433/143344/1/Pan3%282%29_01.2.pdf | accessdate = October 21, 2014}}</ref> With the exception of a 1995 report from Cameroon, where gorillas were considered a target species for hunters, Central and West African hunters do not appear to target them.<ref name="ApeAlliance1998">{{cite book | title = The African bushmeat trade: a recipe for extinction | publisher = Ape Alliance | year = 1998 | url = http://www.insituwildlifeconservation.org/bushmeat.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = October 21, 2014}}</ref> Historically, poachers have favored hunting chimpanzees because they flee when one is shot. Gorillas, however, only became easy targets when [[Shotgun shell#Buckshot|buckshot ammunition]] became available, allowing the hunters to more easily kill the dominant male [[silverback]] whose role it is to defend his troop.<ref name="PanAfricaNews1996"/>
Generally, great apes constitute a minor portion of the bushmeat trade. Although a 1996 study indicated that approximately 1.94% of animal carcasses sold and consumed in [[Brazzaville]] in the [[Republic of the Congo]] belonged to great apes, it accounted for 2.23% of the [[biomass]] of the meat sold, which is significant for ape populations relative to their ecosystem. Furthermore, these numbers may not have accurately represented the extent of the problem for the following reasons:<ref name="ApeAlliance1998"/> # Vendors may not have admitted the sale of great ape meat because it is illegal; # The carcasses are large, and may therefore have been consumed locally rather than been transported to large markets; # Great ape hunting usually peaks when new forest areas are made accessible as they are unwary when unfamiliar with humans, but later hunting declines; # It is nearly impossible to visually distinguish the meat source when it has been smoked; # Secondary effects, such as unintended deaths from traps, are not represented in market data.
During the time interval between a study from 1981 to 1983 and another study between 1998–2002 in [[Gabon]], ape population density fell 56%, despite the country retaining nearly 80% of its original forest cover.<ref name="Nature2003">{{cite journal | author = Walsh, P. D. | author2 = Abernethy, K. A. | author3 = Bermejo, M. | author4 = Beyers, R. | author5 = De Wachter, P. | author6 = Akou, M. E. | title = Catastrophic ape decline in western equatorial Africa | journal = Nature | volume = 422 | issue = 6932 | year = 2003 | pages = 611–614 | doi = 10.1038/nature01566 | url = http://awsassets.panda.org/downloads/ebola_decline_congo_western_equatorial_africa_3.pdf | accessdate = October 21, 2014|display-authors=etal | pmid=12679788}}</ref> This decline was primarily associated with the transformation of the bushmeat trade from subsistence level to unregulated, commercial hunting, facilitated by transportation infrastructure intended for logging purposes.<ref name="PanAfricaNews1996"/><ref name="Nature2003"/> Unsustainable hunting practices along with habitat loss makes the extinction of these endangered primates more likely.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Bowen-Jones | first1 = E. | last2 = Pendry | first2 = S. | year = 1999 | title = The threats to primates and other mammals from the bushmeat trade in Africa and how this could be diminished | journal = Oryx | volume = 33 | issue = 3 | pages = 233–247 | doi = 10.1046/j.1365-3008.1999.00066.x}}</ref>

2009}} Cole also debuted a song from her album, ''3 Words'', titled "[[Parachute (Cheryl Cole song)|Parachute]]", where she danced with [[Derek Hough]], a professional champion of ''[[Dancing with the Stars (U.S. TV series)|Dancing with the Stars]]''.{{cite news|title=Cheryl Cole shows off her glamorous new look as a sexy señorita in TV special|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1235142/Cheryl-Cole-shows-glamorous-new-look-sexy-senorita-TV-special.html|work=[[Daily Mail]]|date=12 December 2009|accessdate=13 December 2009}} ==Setlist== {| class="wikitable" |- !Song !Artist !Notes |- | "[[Fight for This Love]]" | [[Cheryl (singer)|Cheryl Cole]] | Followed by an interview between Cole and presenter [[Holly Willoughby]] |- | "[[Russian Roulette (song)|Russian Roulette]]" | [[Rihanna]] | Followed by a further interview between Cole and Willoughby with a behind the scenes look at the [[The X Factor (UK series 6)|sixth series]] of ''[[The X Factor (UK)|The X Factor]]'' |- | "[[Bad Boys (Alexandra Burke song)|Bad Boys]]" | [[Alexandra Burke]] | Followed by an interview between Cole, Burke and Willoughby |- | "[[3 Words (song)|3 Words]]" | Cheryl Cole and [[will.i.am]] | Followed by an interview between Cole, will.i.am and Willoughby |- | "[[Leave Right Now]]" | [[Will Young]] |rowspan="2"| Each followed by a further interview between Cole and Willoughby |- | "[[Run (Snow Patrol song)|Run]]" | [[Snow Patrol]] |- | "[[Parachute (Cheryl song)|Parachute]]" | Cheryl Cole | Featured dancing accompaniment from [[Derek Hough]] |} ==Reception== Anna Pickard of ''[[The Guardian]]'' described the programme as "an hour of commissioning genius", despite Stuart Heritage of the same publication arguing that "just the title is enough to put you off".{{cite news|first=Anna|last=Pickard|title=The X Factor liveblog - the final shows!|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tvandradioblog/2009/dec/11/x-factor-final-live|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=11 December 2009|accessdate=14 December 2009}}{{cite news|first=Stuart|last=Heritage|title=Cheryl Cole's Night In? Just the title's enough to put you off|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tvandradioblog/2009/nov/24/cheryl-cole-queen-chat|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=24 November 2009|accessdate=14 December 2009}} In a separate article, Heritage voiced his belief that the programme saw Cole "discussing her life in the blandest possible terms while wearing a variety of impractical dresses".{{cite news|first=Stuart|last=Heritage|title=Judge The X Factor, and you get a solo show. But what can Louis Walsh do?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tvandradioblog/2009/dec/16/louis-walsh-encore|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=16 December 2009|accessdate=20 December 2009}} Rick Fulton of the ''[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]'' was complimentary of the programme as he compared the dance routine that accompanied "[[Parachute (Cheryl Cole song)|Parachute]]" to a routine from the programme ''[[Strictly Come Dancing]]''.{{cite news|first=Rick|last=Fulton|title=TV queen Cheryl Cole's takes on the Beeb in ballroom blitz|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/showbiz/television-news/2009/12/12/tv-queen-cheryl-cole-s-takes-on-the-beeb-in-ballroom-blitz-86908-21891724/|work=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]|date=12 December 2009|accessdate=14 December 2009}} [[Alexandra Burke]], who featured in the programme, praised Cole by complimenting her hairstyle and by stating that her performance had "gone up another level".{{cite news|title=Alexandra Burke cannot afford to buy her home|url=http://entertainment.stv.tv/tv/144009-alexandra-burke-cannot-afford-to-buy-her-home/|publisher=[[STV (TV network)|STV]]|date=13 December 2009|accessdate=14 December 2009}} Sian Brewis of the ''[[Leicester Mercury]]'' was critical of the programme; she claimed that it was an "hour-long [[Product placement|plug]] for Chezza's [Cole’s nickname] album", branded Willoughby's questions "vacuous" and compared Cole’s costumes to that worn by characters of ''[[Street Fighter II]]''.{{cite news|first=Sian|last=Brewis|title=TV Review: Cheryl Cole's Night In and X-Factor|url=http://www.thisisleicestershire.co.uk/entertainment/TV-Review-Cheryl-Cole-s-Night-X-Factor/article-1602820-detail/article.html|work=[[Leicester Mercury]]|date=14 December 2009|accessdate=20 December 2009}} Rachel Holmes, writing in ''The Guardian'', was also critical of Cole’s choice of attire and argued that the programme was uninformative. Holmes also claimed that viewers "were suffering from Chezza overload" due to her appearances on ''[[The X Factor (UK)|The X Factor]]'' the same weekend.{{cite news|first=Rachel|last=Holmes|title=Chanel's secret club of 'friends'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2009/dec/17/chanel-secret-club-of-friends|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=17 December 2009|accessdate=20 December 2009}} The programme attracted 5 million viewers, a 22% share of the viewing audience, on its first airing. However, an episode of ''[[Merlin (TV series)|Merlin]]'' and an installment of the [[Strictly Come Dancing (series 7)|seventh series]] of ''[[Strictly Come Dancing]]'', which aired at the same time on [[BBC One]], attracted 5.2 million (25% of the audience) and 8.1 million (33%) respectively.{{cite news|first=Chris|last=Tryhorn|title=TV ratings: More than 12m see Stacey eliminated from The X Factor|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2009/dec/14/tv-ratings-stacey-x-factor|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=14 December 2009|accessdate=20 December 2009}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Cheryl Cole}} [[Category:2009 television specials]] [[Category:British music television programmes]] [[Category:British television specials]] [[Category:ITV television programmes]] [[Category:Music television specials]] [[Category:Television series by ITV Studios]]

{{Expert-subject|Law|ex2=Finance & Investment|reason=needs subject matter expert|date=December 2014}} '''Credit card kiting''' refers to the use of one or more [[credit card]]s to obtain cash and purchasing power they do not have, or pay [[credit card]] balances with the proceeds of other cards. Unlike [[check kiting]], which is illegal under nearly all circumstances, laws against credit card kiting are not completely prohibitive of the practice, thereby allowing it to be done to some degree. It is up to the banks to detect the practice and when necessary, stop it.
In order for prosecution to occur in a credit card kiting scheme, a bank must prove intent to deceive.<ref>{{cite book|title=West's federal reporter|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oXQ1AQAAIAAJ&q=%22Credit+card+kiting%22&dq=%22Credit+card+kiting%22&hl=en&ei=RBjdTsPaDeX30gH9yOSFDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAQ|year=1996|publisher=West Publishing Company, West Group 0 Reviews West Pub. Co.,}}</ref> Et seq. reference infers paying credit card minimum balances with [[credit card]] proceeds is [[de facto]] evidence of deceit.
==Methods== ===Introductory rates=== Many credit cards offer [[introductory rate]]s, which in some cases, could be as low as 0% to which balances from other cards can be transferred. In theory, this enables the endless transfer of balances between cards, and since so many offers are available, this could be carried out for a long period of time. But many banks now have become aware of this practice, and introductory rates are offered only a limited number of times.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.consumercreditcardguide.com/credit-card-blogs/credit-card-kiting|title=What is "Credit Card Kiting"?|accessdate=5 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426022301/http://www.consumercreditcardguide.com/credit-card-blogs/credit-card-kiting|archivedate=26 April 2012|df=}}</ref> In this case, the kiter is delaying legally due balances, and potentially, interest payable to the [[credit card]] bank.
===Cash advances=== [[Cash advance]]s can be obtained from most credit cards, which can be used to pay off balances or loans. Though there are fees and higher interest rates for obtaining these loans, if a card has a high [[credit limit]] or no limit at all, this in theory could be used to pay off the previous balance while adding to the interest. In this case, the kiter is delaying legally due balances, and potentially, interest payable to the [[credit card]] bank; or, in the cited extreme case, using the [[credit card]] proceeds to earn interest at both banks' expense.
===Self payment=== Many payment services, such as [[PayPal]] and [[Square (application)|Square]], allow people to receive credit card payments for low prices, which could be made to oneself. These could be used to pay off balances. In this case, the kiter is creating cash while avoiding legally entitled [[cash advance]] fees. This is a violation of PayPal<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=p/gen/ua/ua-outside|title=Legal Agreements for PayPal Services|accessdate=2 April 2012}}</ref> and Square<ref>{{cite web|url=https://squareup.com/legal/ua|title=square User Agreements|accessdate=2 April 2012}}</ref> [[Terms of Service]] contracts and agreements.
==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Credit cards]] [[Category:Fraud]]

{{Infobox military person |name= Darell Lindsey |birth_date= {{Birth date|1919|12|30}} |death_date= {{Death date and age|1944|08|09|1919|08|09}} |birth_place= [[Jefferson, Iowa]] |death_place= [[Missing in action]] at L'Isle Adam, [[France]] |placeofburial= |placeofburial_label= Place of burial |image= |caption= |nickname= |allegiance={{flag|United States of America}} |branch= [[United States Army Air Forces]] |serviceyears= 1942-1944 |rank= [[Captain (United States)|Captain]] |commands= |unit= [[585th Bombardment Squadron]], [[394th Bombardment Group]] |battles= [[World War II]] |awards= [[Medal of Honor]]
[[Purple Heart]] |laterwork= }} '''Darrell Robins Lindsey''' (December 30, 1919 – August 9, 1944) was a [[bomber]] pilot in the [[U.S. Army Air Forces]] during [[World War II]] and a [[Posthumous recognition|posthumous]] recipient of the [[Medal of Honor]]. ==Biography== Lindsey was born in [[Jefferson, Iowa]], to Jesse Lyle and Grace Alice Lindsey. {{Cite web |last = |first = |authorlink = |coauthors = |year = |url = http://www.homeofheroes.com/gravesites/states/pages_go/lindsey_darrell_ia.html |title = Darrell Robins Lindsey |work = |publisher = Homeofheroes.com |accessdate = July 25, 2006}} After graduating from high school in [[Fort Dodge, Iowa|Fort Dodge]] in 1938, he attended Buena Vista University in [[Storm Lake, Iowa|Storm Lake]] for one year before transferring to [[Drake University]] in [[Des Moines, Iowa|Des Moines]]. He enlisted as an aviation cadet at [[Des Moines#Points of interest|Fort Des Moines]] on January 16, 1942. He trained at [[Visalia Municipal Airport|Visalia]], [[Lemoore]] and [[Victorville Army Airfield|Victorville]] Fields in [[California]], receiving his pilot's wings and commission as a [[second lieutenant#United States|second lieutenant]] in August 1942.{{Cite web|url=https://www.airforcehistory.hq.af.mil/PopTopics/MOH-bios/Lindsey.html |title=Captain Darrell Robins Lindsey |publisher=Air Force historical studies office |accessdate=July 25, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041017095133/https://www.airforcehistory.hq.af.mil/PopTopics/MOH-bios/Lindsey.html |archivedate=October 17, 2004 |df= }} Lindsey was also trained as a [[Bombardier (air force)|bombardier]] at [[Kirtland Air Force Base|Kirtland Field]], [[New Mexico]], and in 1943 was assigned to the 314th Bomb Squadron at [[MacDill Air Force Base|MacDill Field]], [[Florida]], with the rank of [[first lieutenant#United States|first lieutenant]]. He was transferred to [[Battle Creek, Michigan#Transportation|Kellogg Field]], Michigan, in September 1943, and assigned to the 585th Bomb Squadron, 394th Bomb Group (Medium), a [[B-26 Marauder]] outfit. Promoted to [[Captain (United States)|captain]] in December, he was assigned as a flight commander. As part of the [[List of units using the B-26 Marauder during World War II#Ninth Air Force|Ninth Air Force]] the 394th Bomb Group was deployed to [[RAF Boreham]], [[England]], on March 11, 1944, and immediately participated in the bombing of bridges, airfields and the rail system in France in preparation for the [[Operation Overlord|cross-channel invasion]]. On [[D-Day]], the group attacked gun positions in [[Cherbourg]], then continued to support Allied ground units in Normandy by attacking German [[lines of communication]]. In late July, the group changed bases to [[RAF Holmsley South]] in preparation for a move to the continent, and on August 7, 1944, began a three-day campaign against rail and bridge targets in the [[Île-de-France|Île-de-France region]] of northern France for which the group as a whole received a [[Distinguished Unit Citation]].{{Cite web |url=http://www3.uakron.edu/ul/archives/b26/bg-394th.html |title=394th Bomb Group history |publisher=University of Akron |accessdate=July 25, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060519210516/http://www3.uakron.edu/ul/archives/b26/bg-394th.html |archivedate=May 19, 2006 |df= }} [[File:Medalofhonor-lindsey.jpg|thumb|175px|left|Memorial at the [[Lindsey Air Station]], [[Wiesbaden]] before 1993]] On August 9, Captain Lindsey, a veteran of 45 combat missions, flew as group leader to destroy the railroad bridge over the [[Seine River]] at [[Arrondissement of Pontoise|L'Isle Adam]] northwest of [[Paris]]. The bridge, one of the last over the Seine still standing, was heavily defended by German [[anti-aircraft]] units. Leading a formation of 30 aircraft, Lindsey's B-26 was heavily damaged and both the right engine and wing set afire during the bombing run. Although knocked out of formation, Lindsey recovered his place and led the group over the target, then stabilized the aircraft so that his crew could parachute. According to the crew's bombardier, Lindsey severely lessened his own chance to escape to prevent the aircraft from spinning, which proved fatal when a fuel tank exploded just after the last crewman exited the aircraft. Captain Lindsey's body was not recovered and he was listed as [[missing-in-action]] and presumed killed. On May 30, 1945, Lindsey was awarded the Medal of Honor, accepted by his widow, Evalyn Scott Lindsey Rhinehart (1919–1992) during an August 9, 1945, ceremony at First Presbyterian Church in Fort Dodge. In November 1946, [[Lindsey Air Station]], [[Wiesbaden Air Base]], Germany, was named in his memory and served as the location of the Headquarters for the [[United States Air Forces in Europe]]. The station closed in 1993 and a red [[granite]] [[monument]] there was returned to Jefferson, Iowa, and placed on the lawn of the [[Greene County Courthouse (Iowa)|Greene County Courthouse]], where it was dedicated to Lindsey on June 12, 1993.{{Cite web |url = http://www.jeffersoniowa.com/content_display.php?contentId=16§ionId=59 |title = Points of Interest-Lindsey Memorial |publisher = Jefferson Area Chamber of Commerce |accessdate = July 25, 2006}} On the following day at Lindsey's ''alma mater'', [[Buena Vista University]], another memorial was dedicated to Lindsey and [[Ralph Neppel]], also a recipient of the Medal of Honor who had attended Buena Vista. The memorial was donated by Judge Charles Pendleton, a BVU alumnus. Judge Pendleton had earlier made a donation in the memory of Evalyn Rhinehart, who had recently died (August 17, 1992) in a motor vehicle accident, and the wife of a fellow alumnus, Dr. Bruce L. Rhinehart (1922–2010). Pendleton learned that she had been the widow of Darrell Lindsey, and that Lindsey's monument was being returned from Germany. Together, Pendleton and Rhinehart also began the '''Lindsey-Neppel Scholarship''' at Buena Vista in 1993.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bvu.edu/departments/instadvancement/advancement/publications/bvtoday/winter2000/champagne.html |title=Champagne Charlie Pilots BVU scholarship |publisher=Buena Vista Today Winter 2000 |accessdate=July 25, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060905124252/http://www.bvu.edu/departments/instadvancement/advancement/publications/bvtoday/winter2000/champagne.html |archivedate=September 5, 2006 |df= }} ==Medal of Honor citation==
On August 9, 1944, Capt. Lindsey led a formation of 30 B-26 medium bombers in a hazardous mission to destroy the strategic enemy held L'Isle Adam railroad bridge over the Seine in [[Vichy France|occupied France]]. With most of the bridges over the Seine destroyed, the heavily fortified L'Isle Adam bridge was of inestimable value to the enemy in moving troops, supplies, and equipment to Paris. Capt. Lindsey was fully aware of the fierce resistance that would be encountered. Shortly after reaching enemy territory the formation was buffeted with heavy and accurate antiaircraft fire. By skillful evasive action, Capt. Lindsey was able to elude much of the enemy flak, but just before entering the bombing run his B-26 was peppered with holes. During the bombing run the enemy fire was even more intense, and Capt. Lindsey's right engine received a direct hit and burst into flames. Despite the fact that his ship was hurled out of formation by the violence of the concussion, Capt. Lindsey brilliantly maneuvered back into the lead position without disrupting the flight. Fully aware that the gasoline tanks might explode at any moment, Capt. Lindsey gallantly elected to continue the perilous bombing run. With fire streaming from his right engine and his right wing half enveloped in flames, he led his formation over the target upon which the bombs were dropped with telling effect. Immediately after the objective was attacked, Capt. Lindsey gave the order for the crew to parachute from the doomed aircraft. With magnificent coolness and superb piloting, and without regard for his own life, he held the swiftly descending airplane in a steady glide until the members of the crew could jump to safety. With the right wing completely enveloped in flames and an explosion of the gasoline tank imminent, Capt. Lindsey still remained unperturbed. The last man to leave the stricken plane was the [[Bombardier (air force)|bombardier]], who offered to lower the wheels so that Capt. Lindsey might escape from the nose. Realizing that this might throw the aircraft into an uncontrollable spin and jeopardize the bombardier's chances to escape, Capt. Lindsey refused the offer. Immediately after the bombardier had bailed out, and before Capt. Lindsey was able to follow, the right gasoline tank exploded. The aircraft sheathed in fire, went into a steep dive and was seen to explode as it crashed. All who are living today from this plane owe their lives to the fact that Capt. Lindsey remained cool and showed supreme courage in this emergency.

Lindsey] {{DEFAULTSORT:Lindsey, Darrell}} [[Category:1919 births]] [[Category:1944 deaths]] [[Category:United States Army Air Forces Medal of Honor recipients]] [[Category:United States Army Air Forces officers]] [[Category:Aviators killed in aviation accidents or incidents in France]] [[Category:Shot-down aviators]] [[Category:People from Jefferson, Iowa]] [[Category:United States Army Air Forces pilots of World War II]] [[Category:Buena Vista University alumni]] [[Category:Missing in action of World War II]] [[Category:World War II recipients of the Medal of Honor]]

'''Design Commons''' is a deconstructed conference founded by the CEO of Interactive Africa, [[Ravi Naidoo]] in collaboration with World Design Weeks founder [[Kari Korkman]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.helsinkidesignweek.com/events/design-commons/|title=DesignCommons|work=Helsinki Design Week|access-date=2018-05-09|language=en-US}}</ref> The event was established in 2017 and acts as a travelling discussion platform on the future of cities.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dezeen.com/2017/08/09/design-commons-event-helskini-aims-find-solutions-to-world-issues/|title=DesignCommons event in Helsinki aims to find solutions to world issues|date=2017-08-09|work=Dezeen|access-date=2018-04-11|language=en-US}}</ref>
Unlike the conventional conference format, Design Commons places stakeholders in urban planning and public space at the same table as notable designers to foster a sense of common ground and find solutions to some of the world's pressing issues.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.helsinkidesignweek.com/series/ground-breaking-design-conference-to-be-launched-at-helsinki-design-week/|title=Ground-breaking design conference to be launched at Helsinki Design Week - Helsinki Design Week|date=2017-06-07|work=Helsinki Design Week|access-date=2018-04-11|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Background == The first Design Commons event took place in [[Clarion Congress Centre]], [[Helsinki]] as part of the [[World Design Weeks]] summit from 14 to 15 September 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://designcommons.info/|title=DesignCommons - Helsinki|website=designcommons.info|language=en|access-date=2018-04-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ndpculture.org/news/design-commons-at-helsinki-design-week|title=Northern Dimension Partnership on Culture|website=www.ndpculture.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-11}}</ref>
Notable speakers include architect [[David Adjaye]], Dutch architect [[Winy Maas]], Finnish technology entrepreneur Marko Ahtisaari, Dutch landscape architect [[Cees van der Veeken]] and [[Studio Swine]], a collaboration between Japanese architect [[Azusa Murakami]] and British artist [[Alexander Groves]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.designindaba.com/articles/creative-work/design-commons-new-kind-bespoke-global-portable-conference|title=Design Commons is a new kind of bespoke, global, portable conference {{!}} Design Indaba|work=Design Indaba|access-date=2018-04-11|language=en}}</ref>
The event is open to the public and is partially released as a video series on the [[Design Indaba]] website.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.designindaba.com/projects/design-commons|title=Design Commons {{!}} Design Indaba|work=Design Indaba|access-date=2018-04-11|language=en}}</ref>

[[File:Action to stem violence.jpg|thumb|280px|Dhammayietra, an annual peace march in [[Lampatao]], [[Cambodia]] at [[Thailand]] border against [[communal violence]].]]
The '''Dhammayietra''' ({{lang-km|ធម្មយាត្រា}}, "pilgrimage") is an annual peace walk in [[Cambodia]] that originated during the historic repatriation of refugees along the [[Thailand|Thai]] border camps during the [[United Nations]] monitored transition to [[UNTAC|democracy in 1992]]. The Khmer word "dhammayietra", derived from [[Pāli]], ''dhamma'' ([[dharma]]) and [[Sanskrit]] ''yātrā'' ("a walk", "procession"), means "pilgrimage" but is often translated as "pilgrimage of truth". The peace walk takes place in early May and usually involves an assemblage of [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] monks and lay persons who travel various routes in Cambodia.<ref name=PPP97>{{cite news|last1=Fitzgerald|first1=Tricia|title=Dhammayietra|url=http://www.phnompenhpost.com/national/dhammayietra|accessdate=26 October 2015|work=Phnom Penh Post|date=4 April 1997}}</ref>
The assemblage is often greeted by villagers along the route who expect a blessing (''teuk mon'' {{lang-km|ទឹកមន្ត}} or blessing with [[Holy water#Other religions|lustral water]]). The founder of the Dhammayietra was [[Maha Ghosananda]] ({{lang-km|សម្តេចព្រះមហាឃោសានន្ទ}}), a Buddhist monk who ranked among the higher echelons of the Cambodian [[Sangha (Buddhism)|sangha]]; he led the first Dhammayietra as he returned from exile following the war.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Kathryn |last=Poethig |title=Movable Peace: Engaging the Transnational in Cambodia's Dhammayietra |journal=[[Journal for the Scientific Study of Religion]] |year=2002 |volume=41 |issue=1 |pages=19–28 |doi=10.1111/1468-5906.00097}}</ref>
In 1995, the Dhammayietra consisted of almost 500 Cambodian Buddhist monks, nuns and precept-taking lay people. They were joined by [[Peace walk#The Interfaith Pilgrimage for Peace and Life|The Interfaith Pilgrimage for Peace and Life.]] Together the two groups crossed Cambodia from the Thai border all the way to Vietnam, spending several days walking through Khmer Rouge controlled territory along the way.
The 1997 Dhammayietra marched from [[Battambang Province|Battambang]] to [[Pailin Province|Pailin]], which was at the time controlled by the [[Khmer Rouge]], and on to [[Banteay Chhmar]] in [[Banteay Meanchey Province]]. The Khmer Rouge banned monks from their territory in Pailin and prohibited the open practice of religion until 1996 when the majority of Khmer Rouge distanced themselves from [[Pol Pot]] and declared [[Ieng Sary]] their new leader. After this mass defection, monks were tolerated in the area. The 1994 Dhammayietra, which also aimed to march through Pailin failed to reach its destination due to heavy fighting in the province. In Pailin, Ghosananda briefly met with Ieng Sary who respectfully received a blessing but did not attend the official ceremonies. The march, which took place just months before the [[1997 Cambodian Coup]], was unexpectedly joined in Pailin, for 15 kilometers, by [[Sam Rainsy]] and his numerous bodyguards. Rainsy used the opportunity to criticize the absence of the two [[Prime Minister of Cambodia|Prime Ministers]], [[Hun Sen]] and Prince [[Norodom Ranariddh]], who unbeknownst at the time, were embroiled in tensions that would soon erupt into armed fighting between the two and their supporters for control of the government.<ref name=PPP97 />
