repair Pag-asa Island 'illegal', says Chinese envoy|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/05/01/17/ph-plans-to-repair-pag-asa-island-illegal-says-chinese-envoy|accessdate=May 1, 2017|publisher=[[ABS-CBN News and Current Affairs]]|date=May 1, 2017}} The development of the island is expected to include the construction of a marine [[research center]], beaching facilities, a radio station, an [[Commercial production of ice|ice plant]], and a [[power station]], as well as the improvement of the Rancudo airstrip runway.{{cite news|last1=Bartolome|first1=Jessica|title=PHL allocates P1.6-B for Pag-asa Island development|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/news/nation/607856/phl-allocates-p1-6-b-for-pag-asa-island-development/story|accessdate=May 1, 2017|work=[[GMA News Online]]|date=April 21, 2017}} On May 16, 2017, Duterte signed an executive order formally renaming the Benham Rise to the Philippine Rise.{{cite news|last1=Santos|first1=Eimor|title=Benham Rise is now Philippine Rise|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2017/05/12/Benham-Rise-Philippine-Rise-protected-food-supply-zone-Pi%C3%B1ol.html|accessdate=May 22, 2017|publisher=[[CNN Philippines]]|date=May 22, 2017}} In February 2018, the ''[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]'' published aerial surveillance photos of Chinese military fortifications in the South China Sea which showed runways, hangars, control towers, helipads, radomes and multi-storey buildings on reefs across the region, described by the newspaper as "island fortresses". The photos, which were mostly taken in late 2017, were authenticated by the [[Center for Strategic and International Studies]], which described them as "the most complete, detailed batch of aerial pics available", and stated that the "photos show China is nearly done with its militarization of South China Sea". Duterte's spokesman told reporters: "[The region has] long been militarized. And the question is, what can we do?" - which led to accusations of dereliction of his "sacred core duty" of defending Philippine territory.{{cite news|title=Photos show Beijing’s militarisation of South China Sea in new detail|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/06/photos-beijings-militarisation-south-china-sea-philippines|accessdate=19 February 2018|work=The Guardian|date=February 6, 2018}} ====United States==== {{see also|Philippines–United States relations}} [[File:Secretary Kerry Shakes Hands With Philippines President Duterte (28581522615).jpg|thumb|right|Duterte with then U.S. Secretary of State [[John Kerry]], July 26, 2016]] On September 12, 2016, Duterte said that he is "not a fan of the Americans" and that he wants to "reorient" foreign policy with the United States. He requested that [[United States Armed Forces|U.S. forces]] in Mindanao should leave the Philippines, specifically those who are part of the [[Operation Enduring Freedom – Philippines|Operation Enduring Freedom]], saying that it would "inflame the situation with the [[Abu Sayyaf]]".{{cite news|last1=Regencia|first1=Ted|title=Duterte to US forces: Get out of southern Philippines|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/09/duterte-forces-southern-philippines-160913003704576.html|accessdate=October 1, 2016|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=September 13, 2016}}{{cite news |last=Placido |first=Dharel |date=September 12, 2016 |title=Duterte: US forces in Mindanao must go|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/09/12/16/duterte-us-forces-in-mindanao-must-go |publisher=ABS-CBN News |access-date=September 30, 2016}} Duterte said on September 13 that he does not plan to cut ties with the United States, but wants to reiterate the administration's pursuit of an "independent foreign policy" in accordance with the Constitution; the administration will continue to honor mutual agreements like the [[Visiting Forces Agreement (Philippines – United States)|Visiting Forces Agreement]] and the [[Enhanced Defense Cooperation Agreement]].{{cite news |last1=Romero |first1=Alexis |title=Philippines not cutting ties with US – Duterte|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/09/14/1623667/philippines-not-cutting-ties-us-duterte|accessdate=October 1, 2016|work=[[The Philippine Star]]|date=September 14, 2016}} On September 20, Duterte said: "I never said get out of the Philippines, for after all, we need them there in the China Sea. We don't have armaments."{{cite news|last1=Salaverria|first1=Leila|title=Duterte changes tune: We need US after all|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/145192/duterte-changes-tune-need-us|accessdate=October 1, 2016|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=September 21, 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Mendez|first1=Christina|title=We need US for South China Sea – Duterte|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/09/21/1625911/we-need-us-south-china-sea-duterte|accessdate=October 1, 2016|work=[[The Philippine Star]]|date=September 21, 2016}} On September 27, Duterte vowed not to allow the U.S. government to interfere with the policies of his administration. He criticized the U.S. government for "lecturing" his administration on [[human rights]] amidst their campaign on illegal drugs and said that he will "[[Crossing the Rubicon|cross the Rubicon]] with the U.S." Duterte added that he plans to forge "new alliances" with China and Russia in trade and commerce.{{cite news|title=Duterte vows to open up trade, commerce with China, Russia|url=http://www.mb.com.ph/duterte-vows-to-open-up-trade-commerce-with-china-russia/|accessdate=October 9, 2016|agency=[[Xinhua News Agency]]|via=''[[Manila Bulletin]]''|date=September 27, 2016}} [[United States Department of State|U.S. Department of State]] deputy spokesperson Mark Toner responded to Duterte's criticisms by saying that the Philippine–U.S. relations could still remain "strong and unabated" despite Duterte's criticisms.{{cite news|last1=Cabacungan|first1=Gil|title=Duterte seeks alliances with China and Russia|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/145595/duterte-seeks-alliances-with-china-and-russia|accessdate=October 9, 2016|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=September 28, 2016}} The following day, while addressing the Filipino community in [[Hanoi]], Duterte said that the [[Balikatan]] [[military exercise]]s and the joint naval patrols in the South China Sea between the Philippines and the U.S. in October would be "its last" in order to avoid provoking conflict with China.{{cite news|title=Rodrigo Duterte to end joint US and Philippine military drills|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/sep/29/rodrigo-duterte-to-end-joint-us-and-philippine-military-drills|accessdate=October 1, 2016|agency=[[Associated Press]]|via=''[[The Guardian]]''|date=September 29, 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Aurelio|first1=Julie|title=Duterte out to end war games with US|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/145777/duterte-out-to-end-war-games-with-us|accessdate=October 1, 2016|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=September 30, 2016}} [[File:Secretary Tillerson Shakes Hands with President Rodrigo Duterte (36027526740).jpg|thumb|left|Duterte with then U.S. Secretary of State [[Rex Tillerson]], August 7, 2017]] On October 5, Duterte accused the U.S. of refusing to sell armaments to the Philippines and said that he would rather purchase armaments from China and Russia.{{cite news|last1=Krishnamoorthy|first1=Nandini|title=Duterte snubs US again, says he would rather go to Russia and China for purchasing arms|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/duterte-snubs-us-again-says-he-would-rather-go-russia-china-purchasing-arms-1584867|accessdate=October 9, 2016|work=[[International Business Times]]|date=October 5, 2016}} In an attempt to repair relations with the U.S., Duterte's Defense Secretary, [[Delfin Lorenzana]], said Duterte was "misinformed" about the U.S. alliance: "Maybe, the defense ministry and the armed forces were remiss in providing him the correct information."{{cite news|title=Philippine defense chief says Duterte may be 'misinformed' on U.S. alliance|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-usa-military-idUSKCN1251B5|accessdate=October 6, 2016|publisher=Reuters}} On October 6, Duterte's then-Foreign Secretary [[Perfecto Yasay Jr.]] denounced the idea of the Philippines being regarded as a "little brown brother" by the U.S.{{cite news |last=Parameswaran |first=Prashanth |date=September 16, 2016 |title=Philippines No Longer US ‘Little Brown Brother’: Yasay |url=http://thediplomat.com/2016/09/philippines-no-longer-us-little-brown-brother-yasay/ |newspaper=The Diplomat |location= |access-date= }} Yasay said that the Philippines had been "failed" by the U.S.{{cite news |last=Viray |first=Patricia Lourdes |date=October 6, 2016 |time=11:00am |title= Yasay: America has failed us |url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/10/06/1630921/yasay-america-has-failed-us |newspaper=philstar.com |location=MANILA, Philippines |access-date= }}{{cite news |last=Guinto |first=Joel |date=October 6, 2016 |time=10:49 AM |title=America has 'failed' Philippines, Yasay says |url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/10/06/16/america-has-failed-philippines-yasay-says |newspaper=ABS-CBN News |location=MANILA |access-date= }} On October 20, while on a trip to [[Beijing]], Duterte declared a "separation" from the United States which he stated had lost militarily, socially, and economically, and emphasized a realignment of the Philippines to move closer to China.{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-philippines-idUSKCN12K0AS |title=Duterte aligns Philippines with China, says U.S. has lost |publisher=Reuters |date=October 20, 2016 |accessdate=October 20, 2016 |author=Blanchard, Ben}} During a press conference after arriving from Beijing, Duterte clarified that what he meant by "separation" was a "separation of a foreign policy" and not a severance of diplomatic ties, saying that it would not be feasible to cut diplomatic ties with the U.S. due to the large number of [[Filipino Americans]].{{cite news|last1=Salaveria|first1=Leila|title=Duterte: Separation with US doesn't mean cutting diplomatic ties|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/147450/duterte-separation-with-us-doesnt-mean-cutting-diplomatic-ties|accessdate=October 26, 2016|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=October 22, 2016}} U.S. Department of State spokesperson [[John Kirby (admiral)|John Kirby]] responded by saying: "We are going to be seeking an explanation of exactly what the president meant when he talked about separation from the U.S.; it's not clear what that means and all its ramifications."{{cite news|title=US reaction to Duterte's 'separation' announcement|url=http://english.cctv.com/2016/10/21/VIDETIT9qaP5x2ZuptMegTgS161021.shtml|accessdate=October 26, 2016|work=[[CCTV News]]|publisher=[[China Central Television]]|date=October 21, 2016}} On October 23, [[Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs|U.S. Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs]] [[Daniel R. Russel]] traveled to Manila to seek clarification and explanation for Duterte's comments with Philippine officials, including [[Secretary of Foreign Affairs (Philippines)|Foreign Affairs Secretary]] [[Perfecto Yasay Jr.]] and Defense Secretary Delfin Lorenzana.{{cite news|title=U.S. welcomes warmer PH-China ties|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2016/10/24/america-welcomes-relaxation-of-phl-china-relations.html|accessdate=October 26, 2016|publisher=[[CNN Philippines]]|date=October 24, 2016}}{{cite news|title=Daniel Russel: U.S. ‘welcomes easing PH–China ties'|url=http://www.mb.com.ph/daniel-russel-u-s-welcomes-easing-ph-china-ties/|accessdate=October 26, 2016|work=[[Manila Bulletin]]|date=October 24, 2016}} [[File:Donald Trump and Rodrigo Duterte in Manila (3).jpg|thumb|Duterte with U.S. President [[Donald Trump]] in Manila, November 13, 2017]] On November 7, Secretary Lorenzana clarified that the joint Balikatan exercises will continue along with the Enhanced Defense Cooperation Agreement, but the [[Cooperation Afloat Readiness and Training]] [[Amphibious warfare|amphibious landing]] exercises between the [[Philippine Marine Corps]] and the [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] would be discontinued. He specified that bilateral drills on [[counter-terrorism]], [[Humanitarian aid|humanitarian response]], [[special operations]], [[Project management|engineering projects]], and [[Civic action program|civic action]] will remain, all of which have been approved by Duterte.{{cite news|last1=Romero|first1=Alexis|title=Fewer drills with US but EDCA, Balikatan to stay|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/11/07/1641549/fewer-drills-us-edca-balikatan-stay|accessdate=November 7, 2016|work=[[The Philippine Star]]|date=November 7, 2016}} Following the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 U.S. presidential election]], Presidential Communications Secretary [[Martin Andanar]] offered "warm congratulations" to [[Donald Trump]] on his election victory. He said that Duterte "look[ed] forward to working with the incoming administration for enhanced Philippines–US relations anchored on mutual respect, mutual benefit and shared commitment to democratic ideals and the rule of law".{{cite news|title=Duterte congratulates Trump, wishes ‘enhanced PH-US relations'|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/149274/duterte-congratulates-trump-wishes-enhanced-ph-us-relations|accessdate=November 9, 2016|work=Inquirer|date=November 9, 2016}} While in [[Kuala Lumpur]], Duterte personally congratulated Trump by greeting him "''[[Mabuhay|Mabuhay!]]''" and expressed hope that the [[Presidency of Donald Trump|Trump administration]] would honor obligations and treaties signed between the Philippines and the U.S.{{cite news|last1=Corrales|first1=Nestor|title=Duterte softens stance on US, tells Trump: ‘Mabuhay ka’|url=https://globalnation.inquirer.net/149298/duterte-softens-stance-on-us-after-trump-defeats-clinton|accessdate=December 2, 2016|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=November 9, 2016}} On December 2, Duterte called then President-elect Trump to personally congratulate him once more and invited him to visit the Philippines for the [[Twelfth East Asia Summit]] in 2017, while Trump invited Duterte to visit him in [[New York City]] and [[Washington, D.C.]] after the former's [[Inauguration of Donald Trump|inauguration]].{{cite news|title=Trump invites Duterte to White House|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/12/02/16/trump-invites-duterte-to-white-house|accessdate=December 3, 2016|publisher=[[ABS-CBN News]]|date=December 3, 2016}} On April 29, 2017, President Trump called Duterte to inform him of his planned visit to the Philippines in November for the East Asia Summit. Trump also extended an invitation to Duterte to visit him at the [[White House]].{{cite news|last1=Tharoor|first1=Ishaan|title=Trump’s invitation to Duterte is a sign of the times|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2017/05/01/trumps-invitation-to-duterte-is-a-sign-of-the-times/|accessdate=May 1, 2017|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=May 1, 2017}} During their call, Duterte urged Trump to show restraint in dealing with [[North Korea]] over their [[North Korea and weapons of mass destruction|nuclear weapons program]], warning him that the region could suffer "immensely".{{cite news|last1=Panti|first1=Llanesca|title=Trump invites Duterte to White House|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/trump-invites-duterte-white-house/324877/|accessdate=May 1, 2017|work=[[The Manila Times]]|date=May 1, 2017}} Trump also praised Duterte's drug war during the call, telling him "I just wanted to congratulate you because I am hearing of the unbelievable job on the drug problem".{{cite news |author= |date=May 24, 2017 |title=Trump told Duterte "great job" on drug war that’s killed 8,000|url=https://news.vice.com/story/trump-told-duterte-great-job-on-drug-war-thats-killed-8000|work=[[Vice News]]|location= |access-date=May 24, 2017 }}{{cite news |author= |date=May 3, 2017|title= Donald Trump tells Duterte: 'You're doing a great job', Philippines claims|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/may/03/trump-tells-duterte-youre-doing-a-great-job-philippines-claims |work=[[The Guardian]] |location= |access-date=May 24, 2017}} ====ASEAN==== [[File:ASEAN heads of states holding hands 090716.jpg|thumb|Duterte joins other [[ASEAN Summit|ASEAN]] heads of states, holding hands as a symbol of unity in [[Vientiane]], [[Laos]], September 7, 2016.]] Duterte has placed great importance on the Philippines' diplomatic relations with its ASEAN neighbors. Following tradition, his first trips outside the country were to Indonesia, Myanmar, Thailand, Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, Brunei, and Singapore.{{cite news |date=March 16, 2017|title= Duterte to complete Asean swing with visit to Myanmar, Thailand|url= http://globalnation.inquirer.net/153370/duterte-complete-asean-swing-trips-myanmar-thailand}} In 2017 the Philippines was chair and host to the [[2017 ASEAN Summits|ASEAN summits]], a series of diplomatic conferences centering on the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). The culminating event was held in Manila on 10–14 November (31st summit). It was attended by ten Asean leaders.{{cite news |title= LIST: World leaders attending ASEAN 2017 in the Philippines |url= https://www.rappler.com/world/regions/asia-pacific/188021-list-world-leaders-attending-asean-2017-philippines}} ===Economic policy=== {{See also|DuterteNomics}}[[File:Rodrigo Duterte at WEF Forum, Phnom Penh (2017-05-11).jpg|thumb|Duterte speaking at the [[World Economic Forum]] in [[Phnom Penh]], [[Cambodia]], May 11, 2017]] Early in his term, Duterte's expletive-laden outbursts triggered the biggest exodus from stocks in a year and made the peso Asia's worst performer in September 2016. The Philippine currency was at a seven-year low and rounding out its worst month since May 2010. In the same month, the Philippine peso completed its biggest monthly decline since October 2000 amid the biggest outflow from the nation's stocks in a year.{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-30/philippine-peso-completes-worst-month-in-16-years-amid-outflows |title=Philippine Peso Completes Worst Month in 16 Years Amid Outflows |author=Lopez, Ditas B. |work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |date=September 30, 2016 |accessdate=October 7, 2016}} According to the Philippines' Finance Secretary [[Carlos Dominguez]], the peso's slump this year is "mainly due to a deteriorating trade outlook because of rising imports of capital goods, which is normal for a country that is growing very fast".{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-08-16/philippines-in-a-sweet-spot-despite-peso-slump-dominguez-says | title=RP in sweet spot despite peso slump |date=August 17, 2017}} Currency strategists have, however, "predicted a rebound once investors see beyond Duterte's words".{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-29/duterte-s-noisy-peso-rout-out-of-harmony-with-philippine-economy |title=Duterte's Peso Rout Runs Counter to the Booming Philippine Economy |last1=Liau |first1=Y-Sing |last2=Lopez |first2=Ditas B |publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |date=September 29, 2016 |accessdate=October 7, 2016}} After 100 days in office, former president [[Fidel V. Ramos|Ramos]], a political ally-mentor of Duterte said that "Duterte has been a huge disappointment and letdown" and "the government was losing badly by prioritizing a war on drugs at the expense of issues like poverty, living costs, foreign investment, and jobs".{{cite news|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/ex-philippine-president-ramos-says-duterte-government-letdown-060006337.html |title=Ex-Philippine president Ramos says Duterte government a 'letdown' |author=Petty, Martin |website=[[Yahoo!]] |date=October 10, 2016 |accessdate=October 11, 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/10/10/1632214/ramos-dutertes-first-100-days-letdown |title=Ramos: Duterte's first 100 days a letdown |author=Viray, Patricia Lourdes |website=Philstar.com |date=October 10, 2016 |accessdate=October 11, 2016}} Based on subsequent surveys conducted by the [[Social Weather Stations]], optimism in the economic prospects under the Duterte administration remains "excellent" with more Filipinos believing that the quality of their lives will improve in the next 12 months.{{cite web|url=http://bworldonline.com/optimism-excellent-in-q2-sws/ |title=SWS survey shows RP optimism remains excellent | date = August 15, 2017}} This is supported by polls conducted by [[Pulse Asia]] one year after Duterte took office, wherein approval (82%) and trust (81%) ratings for Duterte still remain very high.{{cite web |url=http://www.pulseasia.ph/june-2017-nationwide-survey-on-the-performance-and-trust-ratings-of-the-top-philippine-government-officials-and-key-government-institutions/ |title=Approval and Trust survey for RP Officials |date = June 17, 2017}} Duterte's verbal attacks especially to the US and EU are viewed by many Filipinos as a threat to their jobs especially those working for foreign companies.{{cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/10/24/news/economy/duterte-philippines-us-business/index.html|title=This industry is freaking out over the Philippine president's anti-U.S. rhetoric|first=Pamela|last=Boykoff|date=October 24, 2016|publisher=CNN|accessdate=November 16, 2016}} Mark Williams, chief of Asia economist at Capital Economics, said, "Certainly, investors are worried by some of the things he's saying, he's really unnerved people".{{cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/10/20/news/economy/duterte-investors-philippines-us-china/index.html|title=Rodrigo Duterte: Is the Philippines' outspoken president scaring away investors?|first=Rishi|last=Iyengar|date=October 20, 2016|publisher=CNN|accessdate=November 16, 2016}} The Philippine government, however, expects that employment, especially in BPO industries, will continue to keep on rising.{{cite news|last1=Macas|first1=Trisha|title=BPO industry won’t be affected by Duterte's 'split' with US —Pernia|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/585932/money/companies/bpo-industry-won-t-be-affected-by-duterte-s-split-with-us-pernia|accessdate=December 19, 2016|publisher=GMA News|date=October 21, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161219064333/http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/585932/money/companies/bpo-industry-won-t-be-affected-by-duterte-s-split-with-us-pernia|archivedate=December 19, 2016}} Despite Duterte's bluster and the messy local politics however, the long-term view for the Philippine economy looks good and has even pessimists conceding that gross domestic product should grow close to 7% over the next three to five years. "Twin catalysts of infrastructure spending and tax reform will drive the market over the next two years", Dante Tinga, head of research at BDO Nomura in Manila, tells ''Barron's''. "There's an investment boom under way, which I believe will help in rerating the market over the next 12 months."{{cite web|url=http://www.barrons.com/articles/why-dutertes-stocks-outpace-trumps-1504929378 |title=Why Duterte's Stock Outpaces Trump's |date=September 9, 2017}} In December, government data revealed that the Philippines' output of nickel ore fell 16 percent in the third quarter from a year earlier, after the country, which is the world's top supplier of the metal, suspended some mines in a clampdown on environmental violations. Production dropped to 19.8 million tonnes in the nine months to September from 25.97 million tonnes a year ago, according to the data.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-mining-output-idUSKBN13U0L4|title=Philippines third quarter nickel ore output drops 16 percent as Duterte's green clampdown bites|date=December 5, 2016|publisher=|via=Reuters}} According to Finance Secretary Carlos Dominguez, the "Philippine economy is delivering the performance we anticipated, notwithstanding the political noise and a significant terrorist event in Mindanao". Dominguez gave the assessment during the Banyan Tree Leadership Forum of the Center for Strategic and International Studies.{{cite web|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/business/10/16/17/economy-weathers-political-noise-terror-threat-finance-chief|title=RP economy weathers political noise | date = October 16, 2017}} ===Presidential immunity=== On November 7, 2016, Senator [[Leila de Lima]], Duterte's chief government critic, filed a Supreme Court writ of ''[[habeas data]]'' against Duterte, testing the doctrine of presidential immunity, stating "The verbal attacks on petitioner's womanhood and threats on her person are not covered by presidential immunity from suit because they are not the official act of a President". The 20-page writ asked, "Can a sitting President wage a personal vendetta against petitioner and use the resources of his powerful office to crucify her as a woman, a human being, and a duly elected senator in violation of her right to privacy in life, liberty and security?"{{cite news|title=De Lima challenges Duterte's immunity|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/11/07/1641379/de-lima-challenges-dutertes-immunity|accessdate=November 9, 2016|work=Philippine Star|date=November 7, 2016}} De Lima's counsel, [[De La Salle University College of Law]] dean [[Jose Manuel Diokno]], said "Immunity cannot be used to block this case. There is a blatant violation of the magna carta for women, code of conduct for public officials. We hope the Supreme Court will listen to the plea of Senator de Lima and give consideration to this petition because we believe it is of groundbreaking importance". Duterte had repeatedly criticized De Lima for an alleged adulterous affair with her driver and her alleged "propensity for sex".{{cite news|title=De Lima files test case vs Duterte's immunity from suit|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/841690/de-lima-files-test-case-vs-dutertes-immunity-from-suit|accessdate=November 9, 2016|work=Inquirer|date=November 7, 2016}} He said in August 2016 that she was an "immoral woman" who had no right to criticize the extrajudicial killings because she had "a very sordid personal and official life".{{cite news|title=Duterte blasts female senator: She's 'immoral', an 'adulterer'|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/807080/duterte-blasts-female-senator-shes-immoral-an-adulterer|accessdate=November 9, 2016|work=Inquirer|date=August 17, 2016}} She was subsequently removed from her position chairing a Senate committee investigating the killings, and was then forced to leave her home out of fear for her safety.{{cite news|title=Philippines: Duterte critic Leila de Lima says she fears for her life|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/09/22/asia/philippines-duterte-de-lima/|accessdate=November 9, 2016|publisher=CNN Philippines|date=September 22, 2016}} The writ cited several cases of Duterte admitting that he wanted to drive her to suicide. De Lima demanded to know which foreign country had assisted Duterte in his surveillance of her private conversations, as he had claimed, and how it was carried out.{{cite news|title='Love affair led to corruption'|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/love-affair-led-to-corruption/281280/|accessdate=August 22, 2016|agency=The Manila Times|issue=August 21, 2016|publisher=LLANESCA PANTI}}{{cite news|title=De Lima asks SC for writ of habeas data vs Duterte|url=http://www.interaksyon.com/article/134037/de-lima-asks-sc-for-writ-of-habeas-data-vs-duterte|accessdate=November 9, 2016|work=Inter Aksyon|date=November 7, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161108130224/http://www.interaksyon.com/article/134037/de-lima-asks-sc-for-writ-of-habeas-data-vs-duterte|archive-date=November 8, 2016|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Presidential spokesperson [[Ernesto Abella]] said that "Senator Leila de Lima is apparently playing the gender card as a shield against mounting evidence of her ties with high-profile drug lords and the [[New Bilibid Prison drug trafficking scandal|proliferation of drug trade in the New Bilibid Prison]]". Chief Presidential Legal Counsel [[Salvador Panelo]] said that "the president is immune from suit but even if he is not, the petition has no basis in fact nor in law".{{cite news|title=Palace: De Lima playing gender card as shield|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/11/07/1641390/palace-de-lima-playing-gender-card-shield|accessdate=November 9, 2016|work=Philippine Star|date=November 7, 2016}} Duterte had already made light of the fact of his capacity to give presidential pardons, even with presidential immunity, when he vowed to pardon himself the moment he became president during the 2016 campaign:{{cite web|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/halalan2016/nation/04/28/16/duterte-vows-to-pardon-himself-for-murder|title=Duterte vows to pardon himself for murder|last=France-Presse|first=Mynardo Macaraig, Agence|website=ABS-CBN News|language=en-US|access-date=August 15, 2017}}{{cite news|url=http://time.com/4310651/duterte-philippines-murder-pardon-himself/|title=Philippines' Duterte Says He Will Pardon Himself for Murder|last=Iyengar|first=Rishi|website=Time|access-date=August 15, 2017}} {{Quote|text="Pardon given to Rodrigo Duterte for the crime of multiple murder, signed Rodrigo Duterte"|sign=Rodrigo Duterte to businessmen, 2016 Presidential Campaign|source=}} ==Public image== Rodrigo Duterte developed a reputation as a "protector" and "saviour" in his hometown of [[Davao City]] as Mayor of the city for more than two decades. This is despite reports of death squads in the city.{{cite web|last1=Santos|first1=Ana|title=Rodrigo Duterte’s drug war has killed thousands. Trump just invited him to the White House.|url=https://www.vox.com/world/2017/2/28/14727614/rodrigo-duterte-philippines-drug-dealer-obama-trump-catholic-church|website=Vox|accessdate=29 November 2017|date=1 May 2017}} Rodrigo Duterte has been described as a [[populist]] with his foul-mouthed remarks against the country's elite which positioned him as a "man-of-the-people" as critical to his win in the 2016 presidential elections.{{cite news|title=Duterte, Trump, 'Brexit': Populist surge worldwide|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/overseas/11/10/16/duterte-trump-brexit-populist-surge-worldwide|accessdate=29 November 2017|work=ABS-CBN News|agency=Agence France-Presse|date=10 November 2017}} He has also been compared to US President [[Donald Trump]] for his rhetoric style. ===Supporters=== {{see also|Mocha Uson Blog|Thinking Pinoy}} [[File:President Rodrigo Duterte meets with Filipino community in Indonesia during his working visit in the country on September 9 (3).jpg|thumb|Duterte meets with the [[Filipinos in Indonesia|Filipino community]] in [[Jakarta]], September 9, 2016.]] Ardent supporters of Duterte have been labeled as the "Duterte Diehard Supporters" alternatively known as the "Digong Duterte Supporters" which shares the accronym with the [[Davao Death Squad]] (DDS).{{cite news|last1=Luyag|first1=Margaret Claire|title=‘Hello, mga ka-DDS’: Steven Seagal lauds Duterte’s fight vs. terrorism, drugs|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/showbiz/chikaminute/631207/hello-mga-ka-dds-steven-seagal-lauds-duterte-s-fight-vs-terrorism-drugs/story/|accessdate=12 November 2017|work=GMA News|date=28 October 2017}} This label has been applied to the 16 million people who voted for him during the 2016 presidential elections.{{cite news|last1=Bayoran|first1=Gilbert|title=Alvarez a ‘DDS’ – Diehard Duterte Supporter|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/09/17/1624574/alvarez-dds-diehard-duterte-supporter|accessdate=12 November 2017|work=The Philippine Star|date=17 September 2016}} Several other Facebook groups with the acronym "DDS" supported Duterte as early as 2011. Among these groups is the Duterte Defense Squad which was created on July 5, 2011. Other examples include the Digong Duterte Supporters-Registered Nurses Group, Duterte’s Destiny is to Serve the Country, Digong Duterte Swerte (lit. Digong Duterte is (Good) Luck), and the Davsur Duterte Supporters. In 2015, members of the various groups urged Duterte to run for President.{{cite news|last1=Nawal|first1=Allan|title=Facebook groups add meaning to DDS|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/693793/facebook-groups-add-meaning-to-dds|accessdate=12 November 2017|work=Inquirer Mindanao|date=27 May 2015}} ==Controversy and criticism== {{Criticism section|date=October 2016}} ===Human rights concerns=== In early September 2015, an infamous incident was reported of a tourist being forced to swallow his own cigarette butt in a local bar in Davao City after the tourist refused to comply with the public anti-smoking ordinance of the city. Duterte was personally contacted by the bar owner and went into the bar and forced the tourist to swallow his cigarette butt. Duterte was then met with criticisms especially from the [[Commission on Human Rights (Philippines)|Commission on Human Rights (CHR)]].{{cite news|last1=Gonzales|first1=Yuji Vincent|title=Davao tourist swallows cigarette butt after reprimand from Duterte|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/719038/davao-tourist-swallows-cigarette-butt-after-reprimand-from-duterte|accessdate=December 19, 2016|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=September 3, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905145735/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/719038/davao-tourist-swallows-cigarette-butt-after-reprimand-from-duterte|archivedate=September 5, 2015}} Referring to the arrest of a suspected rice smuggler, Duterte spoke out in the state senate saying, "If this guy would go to Davao and starts [sic] to unload (smuggled rice) ... I will gladly kill him." For these comments, Duterte was attacked in an editorial in ''[[The Manila Times]]'', which condemned "the mentality of lawlessness and vigilantism".{{cite web|title=Duterte and the Law Enforcers' Code of Ethics|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/duterte-and-the-law-enforcers-code-of-ethics/73513/|website=Manila Times |publisher=Manila Times|accessdate=September 6, 2014}} The newspaper argued that this culture of impunity enabled those in power, including officials, "private warlords and businessmen vigilantes" to take retribution against those they felt had acted against their interests: "They kill journalists exposing corruption and human rights activists exposing abusive police and military men." Following Duterte's comments in relation to killing a person suspected of smuggling rice, the office of the President of the Philippines issued a statement saying, "Killing a person is against the law. The President has been firm in the belief that no one is above the law. We must not resort to extralegal methods."{{cite web|title=Palace, CBCP, rights activists gang up on Davao mayor|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/palace-cbcp-rights-activists-gang-up-on-davao-mayor/73307/|website=www.manilatimes.net|publisher=Manila Times|accessdate=September 6, 2014}} [[File:Philippines Drug War Protest 2.jpg|thumb|Protest against the [[Philippine Drug War|Philippine war on drugs]] in front of the Philippine Consulate General in [[New York City]], October 2016]] In October 2016, the French newspaper ''[[Libération]]'' depicted Duterte as a "serial killer president", pertaining to the spate of drug-related killings in the Philippines. The newspaper report drew condemnation from the Filipino community in France. Presidential Spokesperson [[Ernesto Abella]] said in a radio interview that the newspaper's presentation of Duterte as a serial killer was "very unfair" and "irresponsible" while DILG Secretary [[Ismael Sueno]] stated that the description was "too much" and noted the lack of understanding over the administration's war on drugs.{{cite news|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/146418/french-paper-banners-duterte-as-serial-killer-president |title=French paper banners Duterte as ‘serial killer president' |author=Gonzales, Yuji Vincent |website=Inquirer.net |date=October 9, 2016 |accessdate=October 12, 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://www.mb.com.ph/palace-hits-french-dailys-serial-killer-tag-on-duterte/ |title=Palace hits French daily's "serial killer" tag on Duterte |author=Kabiling, Genalyn |work=[[Manila Bulletin]] |date=October 9, 2016 |accessdate=October 12, 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/10/10/1632125/french-newspaper-calls-duterte-serial-killer |title=French newspaper calls Duterte 'serial killer' |website=philstar.com |date=October 10, 2016 |accessdate=October 22, 2016}} As 2016 concluded, the [[Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project]] (OCCRP) nominated Duterte as a runner-up in their ''2016 Person of the Year Award'' that "recognizes the individual who has done the most in the world to advance organized criminal activity and corruption".{{cite web|title=Venezuelan president wins OCCRP person of the year for 2016|url=https://www.occrp.org/personoftheyear/2016/|publisher=OCCRP|accessdate=January 3, 2017}} The OCCRP panel members who recognized Duterte noted his use of "death squads to slaughter drug dealers (and users)", with some panelists comparing his use of vigilante groups to those of the ''2016 Person of the Year Award'' winner, Venezuelan president [[Nicolás Maduro]]. In 2017, the investigative journalists' network [[Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project|OCCRP]] has named Duterte ''Person of the Year in Organized Crime''.{{cite news |title=OCCRP announces 2017 Organized Crime and Corruption ‘Person of the Year’ Award |url=https://www.occrp.org/personoftheyear/2017/ |work=Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project |quote=Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte is the Person of the Year for 2017, according to the Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project (OCCRP), an organization that has for six years recognized the individual who has done the most in the world to advance organized criminal activity and corruption. "Duterte has made a mockery of rule of law in his country", said Drew Sullivan, editor for the Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project and one of the nine judges who made the selection from nominations submitted by journalists and the public. "While he is not your typical corrupt leader, he has empowered corruption in an innovative way. His death squads have allegedly focused on criminals but, in fact, are less discriminating. He has empowered a bully-run system of survival of the fiercest. In the end, the Philippines are more corrupt, more cruel, and less democratic." – Drew Sullivan. Duterte beat out two African strongmen for the title. South African President Jacob Zuma and recently ousted Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe were runners-up. The global panel of nine corruption-fighting journalists, scholars and activists chose Duterte on the strength of his brutal war on drugs. Blunt, swaggering and profane, Duterte has vigorously implemented his pledge to use any tactic necessary to stop drug use. "Hitler massacred 3 million Jews", he declared in a disturbing comparison last year. "There are 3 million drug addicts. I'd be happy to slaughter them."}} Duterte has consistently voiced his grudge against the Commission of Human Rights, much to the dismay of various human rights groups and advocates.{{Cite 2017|work=SunStar|access-date=August 17, 2017|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://thediplomat.com/2017/08/dutertes-latest-target-the-commission-on-human-rights/|title=Duterte's Latest Target: The Duterte asks Gascon|work=Manila Standard|access-date=September 17, 2017|language=en}} The CHR budget was restored by the Senate after thousands of Filipinos have expressed their outrage and dismay against Duterte and his allies in the social media and on the streets.{{Cite news|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/932255/news-liberal-party-chr-people-power-social-media-house-of-representatives-chito-gascon-budget|title=CHR budget restored: 'People power in age of social media'|last=Ager|first=Maila|access-date=September 21, 2017|language=en}} On August 16, 2017, Duterte made another scathing remark against the Commission on Human Rights, threatening them with violence for their probes.{{Cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/08/17/1729880/duterte-shoot-chr-personnel-if-they-obstruct-justice|title=Duterte: Shoot CHR personnel if they obstruct justice|last=Morallo|first=Audrey|work=philstar.com|access-date=August 17, 2017}} {{Quote|text=One of these days, kayong human rights, kayong imbestigahan ko. The criminals have no humanity. God damn it! Marami pang patayan to. Lumalaban talaga yan. (There will be many more killings. They are really fighting back). It will not end tomorrow for as long as there is a drug pusher and drug lord!"|sign=Duterte to the press|source=}} Following the death of Kian de los Santos, a minor allegedly executed by policemen under the admin's [[Philippine Drug War|War on Drugs]], United Nations special rapporteur [[Agnes Callamard]] had implored Duterte to make de los Santos' death the last.{{Cite news|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/news/nation/623432/un-rapporteur-to-phl-make-kian-s-death-the-last/story/|title=UN rapporteur to PHL: Make Kian's death the last|work=GMA News Online|access-date=August 28, 2017|language=en-US}} Duterte had responded by severely cursing Callamard and taunting her to come to the Philippines.{{Cite news|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/160053/duterte-callamard-war-on-drugs-kian-delos-santos-killings-expletive|title=Duterte hurls expletives at Callamard after her remark on Kian slay|last=Corrales|first=Nestor|access-date=August 28, 2017|language=en}} {{Quote|text="Son of a bitch! tell her! The concerned member states include Australia, Brazil, Chile, Costa Rica, Croatia, Czech Republic, Vatican City, Iceland, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Portugal, Sierra Leone, Spain, Slovenia, Switzerland, United Kingdom and United States.{{Cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/05/08/1697944/un-states-ask-philippines-grant-access-callamard|title=UN states ask Philippines to grant access to Callamard|last=Viray|first=Patricia Lourdes|work=philstar.com|access-date=August 30, 2017}} Duterte stated that there is no guarantee that Kian would be the last. news|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/06/28/philippines-dutertes-first-year-human-rights-calamity|title=Philippines: Duterte’s First Year a Human Rights Calamity|date=June 28, 2017|work=Human Rights Watch|access-date=August 18, 2017|language=en}} The Duterte administration suspended the drugs war by February 2017 in an effort to cleanse the police ranks, also halting the disclosure of figures on Secondly, the country where you are elected as President by 16 million out of 100+ million is Third World. You talk as if the Philippines is a superpower. Excuse me, we don't want to go hungry. If you want, you do it yourself. Leave us out of it. So many people have nothing to eat, and yet you'll starve us even further".{{cite web|url=http://entertainment.inquirer.net/203552/actress-agot-isidro-calls-duterte-psychopath-palace-reacts|title=Actress Agot Isidro calls Duterte ‘psychopath’; Palace reacts|first=Yuji Vincent|last=Gonzales|work=inquirer.net|accessdate=November 16, 2016}} Her sentiments were echoed by Senator [[Panfilo Lacson]] adding that "if the economy worsen, the entire Filipino people will be affected, they will go hungry as well".{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/584800/news/nation/lacson-agrees-with-agot-on-duterte-kung-gusto-mo-magutom-magutom-ka-mag-isa|title=Lacson agrees with Agot on Duterte: ‘Kung gusto mo magutom, magutom ka mag-isa’|work=gmanetwork.com|accessdate=November 16, 2016}} Former president Fidel Ramos on his resignation as special envoy to China stated that he did not like Duterte's treatment of US president Barack Obama and lambasted the administration on its refusal to ratify the [[Paris Agreement|Paris Agreement on Climate Change]] which was later agreed by Duterte.{{cite web|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/148483/duterte-on-ramos-hes-a-graduate-of-west-point-i-am-just-a-local-boy|title=Duterte on Ramos: He’s a graduate of West Point, I am just a local boy|first=Totel V. de|last=Jesus|work=inquirer.net|accessdate=November 16, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/11/01/16/duterte-confirms-fvr-resignation-as-special-envoy-to-china|title=Duterte confirms FVR resignation as special envoy to China|first=Aaron Lozada, ABS-CBN|last=News|work=abs-cbn.com|accessdate=November 16, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://manilatimes.net/duterte-ratify-climate-agreement/295390/|title=Duterte to ratify climate agreement|first= Catherine S.|last=Valente|work=manilatimes.net|accessdate=November 8, 2016}} During the [[APEC Peru 2016|2016 APEC Summit]] in Peru, President Duterte skipped two major events due to jet lag. In a press conference at his office in Makati, former president Ramos hit the absence of Duterte at the APEC gala dinner and the shoot for the leaders’ traditional family photo. Ramos said that while Duterte and his Cabinet may have thought that the two events are negligible, it could have disappointed the host country. “Peru President Pedro Pablo Kuczynski must be very disappointed,” Ramos said. He said the gala night could have been an opportunity for Duterte to exchange ideas with world leaders and sickness is an unacceptable alibi to skip such an important gathering.{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/11/22/1646177/fvr-duterte-big-disappointment-peru|title=FVR: Duterte a big disappointment in Peru|publisher=}} In January 2018, Duterte revealed that he advised [[Myanmar]]'s [[Aung San Suu Kyi]] to 'ignore human rights criticisms on Rohingya issue'.http://globalnation.inquirer.net/163689/duterte-suu-kyi-ignore-human-rights-criticisms-rohingya-issue-duterte-myanmar-suu-kyi-rohingya-muslims-asean-meetings In April 5, 2018, Duterte recognized the existence of a [[genocide]] against the [[Rohingya people]].http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/news/nation/649045/duterte-cites-lsquo-genocide-rsquo-in-myanmar-says-phl-will-take-rohingya-refugees/story/ === Catholic Church === [[File:President Rodrigo R. Duterte meets with Luis Antonio Cardinal Tagle.jpg|thumb|President Duterte talks with [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Manila|Manila Archbishop]] [[Luis Antonio Tagle|Luis Antonio Cardinal Tagle]] during a courtesy call at [[Malacañang Palace]], July 19, 2016]] Duterte has referred to the [[Catholic Church]] as "the most hypocritical institution", after the [[Catholic Bishops' Conference of the Philippines]] president [[Socrates Villegas]] released a [[pastoral letter]] indirectly referring to Duterte as a "morally reprehensible" candidate who has shown "scant regard" for the rights of others and the teachings of the Church, urging Filipino Catholics to not vote for him.{{cite news|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/nation/05/22/16/duterte-calls-catholic-church-most-hypocritical-institution |title=Duterte calls Catholic Church 'most hypocritical institution' |author=Punzalan, Jamaine |website=[[ABS-CBN Corporation]] |date=May 22, 2016 |accessdate=November 6, 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/787033/duterte-slams-church-as-hypocritical-institution |title=Duterte slams Church as hypocritical institution |website=Inquirer.net |date=May 23, 2016 |accessdate=November 6, 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/06/27/1597277/duterte-makes-fun-catholic-churchs-practices |title=Duterte makes fun of Catholic Church's practices |website=Philstar.com |date=June 27, 2016 |accessdate=November 6, 2016}} Unlike many prominent [[Social conservatism|conservative]] politicians,{{cite news|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/206612/news/nation/rep-pacquiao-opposes-rh-bill-condom-use |title=Rep. Pacquiao opposes RH bill, condom use |website=[[GMA News]] |date=November 22, 2010 |accessdate=September 24, 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/05/16/manny-pacquiao-gay-marriage-leviticus-examiner_n_1521747.html |title=Manny Pacquiao Against Same-Sex Marriage But Never Said Gay People ‘Must Be Put To Death' |website=[[Huffington Post]] |date=May 16, 2012 |accessdate=September 24, 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://opinion.inquirer.net/33859/the-church-gma-and-the-rh-bill |title=The Church, GMA, and the RH bill |website=Inquirer.net |date=August 1, 2012 |accessdate=September 24, 2016}} Duterte has spoken in favor of birth control, LGBT rights, and reimposition of the [[Capital punishment|death penalty]] which was abolished by President [[Gloria Macapagal Arroyo]], a devout Catholic, during her second term in 2006.{{cite news |last=Corrales |first=Nestor |date=May 22, 2016 |title=Duterte defies Catholic Church's belief on family planning |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/786977/duterte-defies-catholic-churchs-belief-on-family-planning |website=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer|Inquirer.net]] |accessdate=July 13, 2016}}{{cite news|last=Adel |first=Rossette |date=July 13, 2015 |title=Duterte declares support for gay marriage, LGBT rights |url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2015/07/13/1476508/duterte-declares-support-gay-marriage-lgbt-rights |website=[[The Philippine Star|Philstar.com]] |accessdate=July 22, 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/06/22/1595645/duterte-death-penalty-retribution-not-deterrent |author=Romero, Alexis |title=Duterte: Death penalty a retribution not a deterrent |website=[[The Philippine Star|Philstar.com]] |date=June 22, 2016 |accessdate=November 6, 2016}} Upon being elected, Duterte called local bishops "sons of whores", and said he would expand family planning, which the Church had been opposed to. The Catholic Church in the Philippines had lost much of its popularity and political power since being active in overthrowing [[Proclamation No. 1081|the Marcos regime in 1986]]. Antonio Contreras, a political science professor at [[De La Salle University]] in Manila, said that Duterte's attacks on the Church were likely to prove popular.{{cite news|last=France-Presse |first=Agence|date=May 24, 2016 |title=Philippines' Duterte launches vulgar attacks on Church |url=http://www.pri.org/stories/2016-05-24/philippines-duterte-launches-vulgar-attacks-church |website=PRI |accessdate=October 18, 2016}} Duterte was accused of having referred to [[Pope Francis]] as a "son of a whore" during the [[Pope Francis' visit to the Philippines|pontiff's visit to the Philippines in January 2015]] because it caused [[traffic congestion]], though he immediately apologized publicly, explaining he wasn't using these words in regards to the Pope but rather a rant to the government's way of preparing the Pope's visit.{{cite news|last1=Tan|first1=Lara|title=Duterte under fire for comment on Pope Francis|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2015/12/01/Davao-Mayor-Rodrigo-Rody-Duterte-Pope-Francis-traffic-CBCP.html|accessdate=December 19, 2016|work=CNN Philippines|date=December 1, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160425162445/http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2015/12/01/Davao-Mayor-Rodrigo-Rody-Duterte-Pope-Francis-traffic-CBCP.html|archivedate=April 25, 2016}} On December 4, 2015, Duterte, along with his executive assistant [[Bong Go]], visited and talked with [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Davao|Davao Archbishop]] Romulo Valles and Bishop George Rimando, together with Monsignor Paul Cuison to get lectured on Christian Values. Duterte committed to lessen his profanity in public gatherings and even assured that he would donate ₱1,000 to Caritas Davao every time he swears in public. He also stated that he will be planning to visit the [[Vatican City|Vatican]] at a later time.{{cite news |last=Tesiorna |first=Ben |date=December 4, 2015 |title=I will donate P1,000 to Caritas Davao per curse word, Duterte says|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2015/12/04/rodrigo-duterte-donates-P1000-per-curse.html|newspaper=[[CNN Philippines]] |location= |access-date=July 6, 2016}} Duterte however canceled his planned trip and instead wrote a letter to Pope Francis dated January 21, 2016. During a campaign rally in [[Ubay, Bohol]], Duterte's camp showed the letter coming from the Vatican's Secretariat of State, signed by [[Giovanni Angelo Becciu]] dated February 24, stating that Pope Francis had received his letter and that the Vatican appreciated Duterte's apology after allegedly cursing Pope Francis in public.{{cite news|title=Vatican 'appreciates' Duterte's apology after cursing Pope Francis|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2016/04/04/vatican-rodrigo-duterte-apology-cursing-pope-francis.html|accessdate=September 14, 2016|work=CNN Philippines|publisher=CNN Philippines Staff|date=April 4, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160427205320/http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2016/04/04/vatican-rodrigo-duterte-apology-cursing-pope-francis.html|archivedate=April 27, 2016}} In January 2017, Duterte wrote a personal letter to Pope Francis, expressing his gratitude during his papal visit in the Philippines and his "highest esteem and respect" for the pontiff.{{cite news|last1=Macas|first1=Trisha|title=Duterte’s letter to Pope Francis|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/596205/news/nation/duterte-s-letter-to-pope-francis|accessdate=January 18, 2017|publisher=[[GMA Network]]|date=January 18, 2017}} On August 28, 2016, [[Luis Antonio Tagle]], the Archbishop of Manila, acknowledged that people were right to be "worried about extrajudicial killing". He said that it was equivalent to abortion, "unfair labor practices", "wasting food" and selling illegal drugs, explaining that these are all "form[s] of murder".{{cite news|last1=Aurelio|first1=Julie M.|title=Denounce all forms of killings, Tagle urges|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/810940/denounce-all-forms-of-killings-tagle-urges|accessdate=December 19, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161219074537/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/810940/denounce-all-forms-of-killings-tagle-urges|archive-date=December 19, 2016|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=August 30, 2016}} On August 31, in a speech before a gathering of a religious group in Davao City, Duterte said that he once considered being a priest: "It's good I didn't join the priesthood," said Duterte, "or else now I would be a homosexual."{{citation|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/579828/news/nation/duterte-once-wanted-to-be-a-priest-buti-na-lang-hindi-ako-nasali |title=Duterte once wanted to be a priest: ‘Buti na lang, hindi ako nasali’ |author=Macas, Trisha |work=[[GMA News]] |date=September 1, 2016 |accessdate=December 20, 2016}} ===Views on media killings=== The Philippines is one of the most dangerous countries for journalists, with 174 assassinations recorded since the Marcos dictatorship. In a press conference on May 31, 2016, Duterte said that "Most of those killed, to be frank, have done something. You won't be killed if you don't do anything wrong." He appeared to announce his support for killing "corrupt" journalists: "Just because you're a journalist you are not exempted from assassination if you're a son of a bitch". At the press conference where Duterte announced this, he [[wolf-whistling|wolf-whistled]] at a female journalist ([[Mariz Umali]] of [[GMA News and Public Affairs|GMA News]]) when she asked a question.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/misogynistic-philippines-leader-rodrigo-duterte_us_575043bbe4b0eb20fa0ce55e|title=Misogynistic Philippines Leader Duterte Continues To Disrespect Women |last=Cook |first=Jesselyn|date=June 2, 2016|website=Huffington Post|access-date=June 25, 2016}} At a news conference on the following day he defended his comments and refused to apologise, telling reporters, "I cannot protect you". He has been criticized by foreign and domestic media organizations regarding his comments.{{cite news|title=Philippines' Duterte offers no apology for attacks on media |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-philippines-politics-idUSKCN0YO26V|accessdate=November 16, 2016|publisher=Reuters|date=June 2, 2016}} The Southeast Asia representative of the Committee to Protect Journalists said: "What he has done with these irresponsible comments is give security officials the right to kill for acts that they consider defamation. This is one of the most outrageous statements we have ever heard from a president in the Philippines."{{cite news|title=Media groups condemn Rodrigo Duterte comments on corrupt journalist|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jun/01/media-groups-condemn-rodrigo-duterte-comments-journalists-philippines|accessdate=June 6, 2016|agency=[[Agence France Presse]]|via=''[[The Guardian]]''|date=June 1, 2016}} Melinda Quintos de Jesus, executive director of the Center for Media Freedom, stated in October 2016 that major newspapers and television stations have not critically analyzed Duterte's policies, because "they fear him. They basically are afraid to be singled out."{{cite news|title=Rodrigo Duterte, Scorned Abroad, Remains Popular in the Philippines|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/14/world/asia/philippines-rodrigo-duterte-rating.html|accessdate=October 16, 2016|work=New York Times|date=October 13, 2016}} Despite his rocky relationship with the media, Duterte's first Administrative Order was the creation of a Presidential Task Force on Media Security, whose main task is conduct an inventory of cases of media killings, including unsolved cases, cases under investigation, cases under preliminary investigation, cases under trial, and cases under appeal, and "to put an end to all forms of political violence and abuses of powers against members of the fourth estate."{{cite web|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/task-force-vs-media-killings-hailed/335627/ | title = Media workers hail task force}}{{cite web|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/10/13/16/duterte-creates-task-force-on-media-killings | title = Duterte creates task force to protect media}} In the first year that Duterte took office, four journalists were killed.{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/08/11/philippine-journalist-killings-demand-state-action | title = Philippine Journalist Killings Demand State Action }} . === Personal killings === Duterte has repeatedly admitted to killing three people while he was the Mayor of Davao. In December 2015, Duterte recounted shooting three gunmen dead only months into his first mayoral term in 1988 after they had kidnapped and raped a Chinese girl. He justified his actions, saying "they were committing a crime in my presence and I was the person in authority under the law".{{cite web|last1=dela Cruz|first1=Kathlyn|title=Duterte confirms killing 3 rapist-kidnappers|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/halalan2016/nation/12/09/15/duterte-confirms-killing-3-rapist-kidnappers|publisher=[[ABS-CBN]]|accessdate=December 19, 2016}} In an interview with BBC on December 16, 2016, he said: "I killed about three of them, because there were three of them. I don't know how many bullets from my gun went inside their bodies. It happened, and I said, I cannot lie about it".{{cite web|title=Philippines: Duterte confirms he personally killed three men|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-38337746|publisher=BBC|accessdate=December 19, 2016}} On December 14, 2016, Duterte gave a speech to business leaders in the presidential palace where he spoke of personally killing suspected criminals as Mayor of Davao to set an example for local police. He said, "In Davao I used to do it personally. Just to show to the guys that if I can do it why can't you. And I'd go around in Davao with a motorcycle, with a big bike around, and I would just patrol the streets, looking for trouble also."{{cite web|title=Duterte says he patrolled streets looking for criminals to kill|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bsEgGVXZkZc|publisher=[[Daily Mail]]|accessdate=December 19, 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Goldman|first1=Russell|title=Rodrigo Duterte on Killing Criminal Suspects: ‘I Used to Do It Personally’|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/14/world/asia/rodrigo-duterte-philippines-killings.html?_r=0|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=December 19, 2016}} ===War on Drugs=== {{Further information|Philippine Drug War}} [[File:Rodrigo Roa Duterte.jpg|thumb|Duterte during his visit to [[Bacolod]] for the [[Masskara Festival]]]] Despite constant criticism of his war on drugs, Duterte had staunchly defended his administration efforts at getting rid of "filth" from the streets.{{Cite news|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/876993/duterte-renews-attack-on-church-as-he-defends-war-on-drugs|title=Duterte renews attack on Church as he defends war on drugs|last=Bunachita|first=Jose Santino S.|access-date=August 18, 2017|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/duterte-defends-war-on-drugs-slams-us-in-singapore-speech|title=Duterte defends war on drugs, slams US in Singapore speech|last=seokhwai@st|date=December 16, 2016|work=The Straits Times|access-date=August 18, 2017|language=en}} Duterte had even called [[César Gaviria]] an "idiot".{{Cite news|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/3235074/rodrigo-duterte-rejects-advice-cesar-gavira/|title=Duterte defends drug war, rejects advice of ‘idiot’ ex-Colombia president|work=Global News|access-date=August 18, 2017|language=en}} This was after he read Gaviria's opinion that was published in ''The New York Times''. Gaviria claimed that Duterte is simply repeating his mistakes during his term as president when he used heavy-handed means in Colombia's war against drugs.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/07/opinion/president-duterte-is-repeating-my-mistakes.html|title=President Duterte Is Repeating My Mistakes|last=Gaviria|first=César|date=February 7, 2017|work=The New York Times|access-date=August 18, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} Duterte said Gaviria was “lecturing” and the Philippine case was different to Colombia. Various international publications and media companies had claimed that Duterte's "War on Drugs" was a war against the poor due to the abject poverty of those arrested or killed.{{cite news|url=http://time.com/4462352/rodrigo-duterte-drug-war-drugs-philippines-killing/|title=The Killing Time: Inside Rodrigo Duterte's Drug War|last=Manila|first=Rishi Iyengar /|website=Time|access-date=August 18, 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2017/02/war-on-drugs-war-on-poor/|title=Philippines: Duterte's 'war on drugs' is a war on the poor|website=www.amnesty.org|language=en|access-date=August 18, 2017}} In 2017, the investigative journalists' network [[Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project|OCCRP]] reported that "Duterte has overseen the killing of more than 7,000 and possibly as many as 12,000. The statistics are hard to pin down because Duterte’s National Police suppress all critical reports. And police are spared from any accountability or legal consequences for a campaign that has left bodies in the streets." On August 18, 2017, Duterte admitted his mistake in trying to end drugs in six months, and it would take him his entire term to end it.{{Cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/08/18/1730277/6-years-drug-war|title=‘6 years for drug war’|last=Romero|first=Alexis|work=philstar.com|access-date=August 18, 2017}} Duterte stated that he had no idea when he took office that Philippines had become a failed state, having been degenerated into a [[narco-state]]. He blamed the [[Bureau of Customs]] whose people he thought were loyal to him. He also blamed the governors, mayors and policemen who were involved in drugs and threatened to have them killed.{{Cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/08/17/1730136/duterte-admits-he-was-wrong-about-6-month-deadline-vs-drugs|title=Duterte admits he was wrong about 6-month deadline vs drugs|last=Romero|first=Alexis|work=philstar.com|access-date=August 18, 2017}} The Duterte administration had been using a "narco-list" which Duterte shares with the mass media to warn public officials allegedly involved in the drug trade to surrender.{{Cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/08/17/1730085/updated-narco-list-now-pnp-chiefs-hands|title=Updated ‘narco-list’ now in PNP chief's hands|last=Bolando|first=AJ|work=philstar.com|access-date=August 18, 2017}} Duterte claims to have received several death threats because of his campaign against drugs. Unfazed by these, Duterte stated that he welcomes all attempts to kill him.{{Cite news|url=http://manilastandard.net/news/top-stories/245969/i-welcome-death-threats-duterte.html|title=I welcome death threats — Duterte|work=Manila Standard|access-date=September 1, 2017|language=en}} Several senators have implored the public to express more outrage at Duterte's War on Drugs.{{Cite news|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/923723/senate-of-the-philippines-senator-kiko-pangilinan-drug-deaths-war-on-drugs-anti-drug-operations-drug-problem-poor-filipinos-customs-jv-ejercito-grace-poe|title=Senators express alarm over high number of drug deaths|last=Jesus|first=Jhoanna Ballaran, Julliane Love De|access-date=August 18, 2017|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/08/18/1730298/leni-drug-deaths-people-must-express-outrage|title=Leni on drug deaths: People must express outrage|last=Lee-Brago|first=Pia|work=philstar.com|access-date=August 18, 2017}} ==Personal life== Duterte is known for being an avid fan of [[Cruiser (motorcycle)|big bike]]s but detests luxury cars. He once owned a second-hand [[Harley-Davidson]] and currently a [[Yamaha Virago]]. He was once a habitual [[smoking|smoker]], but he eventually quit after a doctor's suggestion due to health concerns. Duterte is an avid reader of [[Robert Ludlum]] and [[Sidney Sheldon]] novels.{{cite news |last1=Ranada |first1=Pia |last2=Caduaya |first2=Editha |date=September 18, 2015 |title=22 things to know about 'Duterte Harry' |url=http://www.rappler.com/newsbreak/iq/105955-things-know-trivia-rodrigo-duterte |publisher=''[[Rappler]]'' |location= |access-date=July 6, 2016}} Duterte is also known for his straightforward and vocal attitude in public especially in interviews, showing no hesitation in using [[profanity]] profusely live on-screen on numerous occasions despite formal requests by media groups and schools beforehand to abstain.{{cite web|url=https://durianburgdavao.wordpress.com/2015/05/16/the-dutertes-in-davao-city-politics/|title=The Dutertes in Davao City Politics|work=Durian Post by DurianburgDavao}}{{cite news |last=Regalado |first=Edith |date=March 3, 2001 |title=Davao City Mayoral Race; Duterte siblings slugging it out |url=http://www.philstar.com/nation/104586/davao-city-mayoral-race-duterte-siblings-slugging-it-out |newspaper=''[[The Philippine Star|Philstar]]'' |location= |access-date=July 6, 2016}} Duterte has his own local show in Davao City called ''Gikan Sa Masa, Para Sa Masa'' ("From the Masses, For the Masses") aired as a [[block programming|blocktimer]] on [[DXAS-TV|ABS-CBN Davao]]. He is also a member of [[Lex Talionis Fraternitas]], a fraternity based in the [[San Beda College of Law]] and the [[Ateneo de Davao University]].{{cite news |last=Monforte |first=Cha |date=April 15, 2015 |title=2 Duterte aides hurt in accident |url=http://www.businessmirror.com.ph/2-duterte-aides-hurt-in-accident |newspaper=[[BusinessMirror]] |location= |access-date=July 6, 2016}} Aside from his native [[Cebuano language|Cebuano]], Duterte is also fluent in [[Filipino language|Filipino]] and [[English language|English]].{{cite news |last=Apostol |first=Gina |date=May 29, 2017 |title=Speaking in Fascism’s Tongues |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/19/opinion/sunday/philippines-rodrigo-duterte-fascism.html |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |location= |access-date=February 25, 2018}} ===Family=== [[File:Rodrigo Duterte and children at inauguration ceremony 6.30.16.jpg|thumb|Duterte's children (from left to right): Sebastian, Veronica, [[Sara Duterte|Sara]] and [[Paolo Duterte|Paolo]] escort their father (center) to his [[Inauguration of Rodrigo Duterte|inauguration ceremony]], June 30, 2016]] [[File:Rodrigo Duterte and Cielito Avanceña family portrait.jpg|thumb|Duterte with Avanceña along with their daughter, Veronica]] Duterte was once married to [[Elizabeth Zimmerman|Elizabeth Abellana Zimmerman]], a flight attendant from Davao City and is of [[Jewish]] [[German American]] descent who also traces her roots in [[Tuburan, Cebu]]. They together have three children (from eldest to youngest): [[Paolo Duterte|Paolo]] ("Pulong"), [[Sara Duterte|Sara]] ("Inday Sara") and Sebastian ("Bastê"). Paolo and Sara ventured into politics while Baste, with no interest in politics, concentrated on business and surfing. In 2012, Duterte made a notorious remark in a media interview regarding an incident where Paolo's name was allegedly linked to a carnapping ([[portmanteau]] of car and [[kidnapping]]) syndicate led by Ryan Yu. Duterte is infamously quoted as having said: "Kill my son Paolo if he is involved in crime." Paolo was never charged for lack of evidence and eventually won the Davao City vice mayoralty in 2013.{{cite news|last1=Balanza|first1=Roger M.|title=Rody Duterte: Kill my son Paolo if he is involved in crime|url=https://durianburgdavao.wordpress.com/2012/10/28/rody-duterte-kill-my-son-paolo-if-he-is-involved-in-crime/|accessdate=September 14, 2016|work=The Durian Post|date=October 28, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304141142/https://durianburgdavao.wordpress.com/2012/10/28/rody-duterte-kill-my-son-paolo-if-he-is-involved-in-crime/|archivedate=March 4, 2016}} Duterte's father Vicente died in 1968 while his mother Soledad died on February 4, 2012, at the age of 95.{{cite news |last=Lacorte |first=Germelina |date=February 5, 2012 |title=Duterte matriarch dies at 95 |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/140077/duterte-matriarch-dies-at-95 |newspaper=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer|Inquirer.net]] |location= |access-date=July 6, 2016}} Zimmerman was diagnosed with [[Cancer staging|stage 3]] [[breast cancer]] in 2015.[http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/561578/news/nation/duterte-s-ex-wife-skips-cancer-treatments-to-launch-campaign-caravan Duterte's ex-wife skips cancer treatments to launch campaign caravan – ''GMA News Online''.] Duterte has been publicly very open about his infidelity and philandering while married to Zimmerman and cited it as the reason for his failed first marriage when asked in interviews. In 1998, Zimmerman filed a petition with the [[Regional Trial Court]] in [[Pasig]] to nullify her marriage. Duterte never appeared in court and did not contest Zimmerman's petition. Two years later, the court decided in her favor, ending the 27-year marriage of Duterte and Zimmerman. Duterte and Zimmerman have been on good terms in recent years with Zimmerman stating, "Yes, [Rodrigo] is really a very good leader. That is all he is. But when it comes to family, he is not capable of taking care of it." In 2001, Zimmerman eventually ran for a seat on the city council but lost. Duterte and Zimmerman are said to have patched things up and appear to be civil to each other, 15 years after their marriage was declared null and void. Zimmerman eventually joined the campaign trail for Duterte's presidential candidacy in early 2016 called ''Byaheng Du30'' in which she would travel by bus to major cities together with her daughter Sara and a number of delegates. Duterte is currently living with his [[common-law marriage|common-law wife]] Cielito "Honeylet" Avanceña, a nurse, with whom he has one daughter named Veronica ("Kitty"). Duterte has eight grandchildren, half of whom are Muslims and the other half Christian.{{cite news|title=Duterte wants conflict with Muslims settled|url=http://boholnewstoday.com/201501/duterte-wants-conflict-with-muslims-settled.html|accessdate=September 14, 2016|work=Bohol News Today|date=January 13, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160603155536/http://boholnewstoday.com/201501/duterte-wants-conflict-with-muslims-settled.html|archivedate=June 3, 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Ledesma|first1=Jun|title=Calling Duterte|url=http://archive.sunstar.com.ph/davao/opinion/2015/02/12/ledesma-calling-duterte-391700|accessdate=September 14, 2016|work=Sun.Star Davao|date=February 12, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150930011541/http://archive.sunstar.com.ph/davao/opinion/2015/02/12/ledesma-calling-duterte-391700|archivedate=September 30, 2015}} ===Ancestry=== On his paternal side, he shares familial ties with some of the prominent families of the Visayas, particularly the Almendrases & Duranos of [[Danao, Cebu]].{{efn|name="duterte-durano-almendras"|Brothers Facundo & Severo Duterte both married women from Danao; Severo's daughter Beatriz married post-War business magnate Ramon M. Durano, Sr. Their descendants constitute the modern-day political family of the Duranos of [[Danao, Cebu]]. Ramon M. Durano, Sr.'s sister Elisea married Paulo Almendras, and their descendants constitute the modern-day Almendrases of Cebu. One of their descendants, [[Jose Rene Almendras]] is a former [[Secretary of Foreign Affairs (Philippines)|Secretary of the Department of Foreign Affairs (acting)]].{{cite news|url=http://www.edgedavao.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=23920:the-duterte-bloodline&catid=51:on-the-cover&Itemid=265|title=The Duterte Bloodline|date=December 5, 2015|work=EDGE Davao|last1=Figueroa|first1=Antonio V.|accessdate=September 14, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160914162402/http://www.edgedavao.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=23920:the-duterte-bloodline&catid=51:on-the-cover&Itemid=265|archivedate=September 14, 2016}}}} ===Religion=== Despite being raised as a communicant of the [[Catholic Church]], on January 19, 2016, while meeting with businessmen in [[Binondo]], Manila, Duterte clarified that he has not attended [[Mass in the Catholic Church|Mass]] for quite some time already since he deemed it incompatible with his mayoral responsibilities: "If I listened to the [[Ten Commandments]] or to the priests" said Duterte, "I would not be able to do anything as a mayor". He then clarified that he still believes in God, but not in religion.{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2016/05/20/1585212/duterte-says-he-believes-god-not-religion |last=Romero |first=Alexis |title=Duterte says he believes in God but not in religion |website=Philstar.com |date=May 20, 2016 |accessdate=September 2, 2016}} On June 26, 2016, Duterte said he's [[Christianity|Christian]], but also said that he believes "in one god [[Allah]]".{{cite news|url=http://www.christiantoday.com/article/duterte.vows.to.promote.birth.control.in.the.philippines.says.hes.a.christian.but.believes.in.one.god.allah/89535.htm |title=Duterte vows to promote birth control in the Philippines, says he's a Christian but believes 'in one god Allah' |author=Torres, Hazel |work=[[Christian Today]] |date=June 29, 2016 |accessdate=November 6, 2016}} In July 2018, he called himself "[[Spiritual but not religious|spiritual]]" and expressed his belief in "one Supreme [[God]]", but stated he "can't accept" [[Catholicism]] or [[organised religion]].{{cite web|url=https://www.newshub.co.nz/home/world/2018/07/rodrigo-duterte-doubles-down-on-attack-on-god-asks-for-proof.html|title=Rodrigo Duterte doubles down on attack on God, asks for proof|date=July 8, 2018|publisher=}} ===Health=== Duterte has [[Thromboangiitis obliterans|Buerger's disease]], an inflammation of blood vessels, mostly in the limbs, and [[Barrett's esophagus]], wherein esophageal cells are gradually replaced by gastrointestinal cells. He has denied rumors of [[throat cancer]].{{cite news|last1=Frialde|first1=Mike|title=Duterte: I may not last 6 years in office|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2015/12/10/1531028/duterte-i-may-not-last-6-years-office|accessdate=December 17, 2015|work=The Philippine Star|date=December 10, 2015}} ===Prescription drug use=== Duterte admitted in December 2016 that he had been a user of the addictive [[opioid]] drug [[Fentanyl]]. He said that a doctor prescribed the drug to alleviate back pain and headaches, but that he would take more than he was prescribed: "I was only given a fourth of [the whole patch], but no more, because, of course, my doctor learned that I was using the whole patch because I felt better".{{cite news|title=Philippines President Duterte admits killing suspects|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/12/14/asia/duterte-philippines-davao-killings/|accessdate=December 17, 2016|work=CNN|date=December 14, 2016}} Fentanyl is described by the US [[National Institute on Drug Abuse]] as "a powerful synthetic opioid analgesic that is similar to [[morphine]] but is 50 to 100 times more potent".{{cite news|title=Duterte’s painkiller too strong to prescribe, says medical specialist|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/592535/lifestyle/healthandwellness/duterte-s-painkiller-too-strong-to-prescribe-says-medical-specialist|accessdate=December 15, 2016|work=GMA|date=December 15, 2016}} Duterte later denied that he was a drug addict, and a spokesman stated that he was not affected by side-effects of the drug, which include confusion, anxiety and [[hallucination]]s.{{cite news|title=Philippines: Duterte confirms he personally killed three men|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-38337746|accessdate=December 17, 2016|work=BBC|date=December 16, 2016}} Duterte has boasted about his use of [[Viagra]]: "When I was young, I could do overnight, which is more expensive. When I got old, I could do short time only because I have such a short time left. After one erection, that's it. No more. Without Viagra, it's even more difficult."{{cite news|title=Duterte's shocking, shrewd shot at the Philippine presidency|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/duterte-s-shocking-shrewd/2761902.html|accessdate=October 5, 2016|work=Channel NewsAsia|date=May 6, 2016}}{{cite news |last=Ranada |first=Pia |date=November 30, 2015 |title=Rodrigo Duterte: Yes, I'm a womanizer |url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/politics/elections/2016/114416-rodrigo-duterte-womanizer |publisher=''[[Rappler]]''
